class=\"ww-citation-primary\"><em>Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</em>, Volume 489, Issue 2, October 2019, Pages 2525\u20132535, <a href='https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/stz2200'>https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/stz2200</a></div>\r\n        </div>\r\n        <div class=\"pub-history-row clearfix\">\r\n            <div class=\"ww-citation-date-wrap\">\r\n                <div class=\"citation-label\">Published:</div>\r\n                <div class=\"citation-date\">12 August 2019</div>\r\n            </div>\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"ww-citation-history-wrap js-article-history st-article-history\">\r\n                    <span>Article history</span><i class=\"icon-general-arrow-filled-down        <div class=\"wi-state\">Received:</div>\r\n                    <div class=\"wi-date\">28 May 2018</div>\r\n                </div>\r\n                <div class=\"history-entry\">\r\n                    <div class=\"wi-state\">Accepted:</div>\r\n                    <div class=\"wi-date\">06 August 2019</div>\r\n                </div>\r\n                <div   <li class=\"toolbar-item item-pdf\">\r\n        <a class=\"al-link pdf article-pdfLink\" data-article-id=\"5548822\" href=\"/mnras/article-pdf/489/2/2525/29809292/stz2200.pdf\">\r\n            <img src=//oup.silverchair-cdn.com/UI/app/svg/pdf.svg alt=\"pdf\" /><span class=\"pdf-link-text\">PDF</span>\r\n        </a>\r\n    </li>\r\n                                                    <li class=\"toolbar-item item-link item-split-view\">\r\n                                <a href=\"javascript:;\"\r\n                                   class=\"split-view js-split-view st-split-view\"\r\n                                   target=\"\">\r\n                                    <i class=\"icon-menu_split\"></i>\r\n                                    Split View\r\n                                </a>\r\n                            </li>\r\n                        <li class=\"toolbar-item item-with-dropdown item-views\">\r\n                            <a class=\"at-views-dropdown drop-trigger\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-dropdown=\"FilterDrop\" aria-haspopup=\"true\">\r\n                                <i class=\"icon-menu_views\"></i>\r\n                                <div class=\"toolbar-label\">\r\n                                    <div class=\"toolbar-text\">Views</div>\r\n                                    <i class=\"icon-general-arrow-filled-down               <li class=\"at-figures-tables article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"figures-tables\">\r\n                                    <a class=\"toolbar-item\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ToolboxGetCitation widget-instance-OUP_Get_Citation\">\n        <a href=\"#\" class=\"js-cite-button\" data-reveal-id=\"getCitation\"       </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input     <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=157796214 id=\"157796214\" class=\"abstract-title\" >ABSTRACT</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We have scanned 5000\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> of Southern Sky to search for strongly lensed quasars with five methods, all source oriented, but based on different assumptions and selection criteria. We present a list of high-grade candidates from each method (totalling 98 unique, new candidates), to facilitate follow-up spectroscopic campaigns, including two previously unknown quadruplets, WG\u00a0210014.9-445206.4 and WG\u00a0021416.37-210535.3. We analyse morphological searches based on <em>Gaia</em> multiplet detection and astrometric offsets, fibre-spectroscopic pre-selection, and X-ray and radio pre-selection. The performance and complementarity of the methods are evaluated on a common sample of known lenses in the Dark Energy Survey public Data Release 1 (DR1) footprint. We recovered in total 13 known lenses, of which 8 are quadruplets. Morphological and colour selection of objects, from the <em>WISE</em> and<em>Gaia</em>-DR2 surveys, recovers most of those known lenses, but searches in the radio and X-ray cover regimes that are beyond the completeness of <em>Gaia</em>. Given the footprint, pre-selection, and depth limits, the current number of quads indicates that the union of these searches is complete, and the expected purity on high-grade candidates is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\approx}60{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>. Ongoing, spectroscopic campaigns confirm this estimate.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"catalogues\">catalogues</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: formation&quot;\">galaxies: formation</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;dark matter&quot;\">dark matter</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=157796216 id=\"157796216\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Sizeable samples of gravitationally lensed quasars, spanning a range in redshift, image separation, and mass, are essential to various scientific purposes. However, these objects are extremely rare: according to Oguri\u00a0&amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a>), one in \u224810<sup>4</sup> quasars is strongly lensed. One of the first efforts to build a large and well-studied statistical sample of strong gravitational-lensed quasars has been made by The Cosmic Lens All-Sky Survey (CLASS; Myers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>). CLASS has obtained high-resolution radio images from the Very Large Array (VLA; at 8.4\u00a0GHz) of over 13\u00a0000 flat-spectrum radio sources, finding 22 radio-loud lenses. However, in radio lens surveys like CLASS, the redshift distribution of the flat-spectrum sources is poorly constrained (e.g. Mu\u00f1oz et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>). Only with the advent of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS; York et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>), which in its 14th Data Release confirmed 526\u00a0356 quasars spectroscopically (P\u00e2ris et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), has it been possible to construct a large sample of lensed quasars also in the optical (e.g. The Sloan Digital Sky Survey Quasar Lens Search, SQLS; Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), beyond the bright lenses identified in older searches.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">More recently, thanks to new imaging sky surveys, with wide footprints and sufficient depth and image quality, like ATLAS (Shanks et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), DES (The Dark Energy Survey Collaboration <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; The Dark Energy Survey Collaboration et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), and KiDS (de Jong et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), the search for lensed quasars has received new impetus. Nevertheless, to this day, a big portion of the Southern Sky still remains unexplored and the spatial density on sky of known lenses remains much higher at Dec. &gt; 0.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to fully exploit the wealth of data from different surveys, a suite of new methods to search for lensed quasars (QSOs) have been developed, based on morphology and visual inspection (Diehl et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Lin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>); spectroscopy (e.g. Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>); data mining on catalogue magnitudes (Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015a</a>; Agnello <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Williams, Agnello\u00a0&amp; Treu <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>); and variability (Berghea et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As recently quantified by Spiniello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), different search methods are somewhat complementary, as each search relies on different criteria and ancillary information. The application of multiple, state-of-the-art methods over the same footprint then serves two scopes: assessing the role of selection bias in lens samples; and maximizing purity and completeness in lens searches.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">With this paper, we perform a comparison study over the footprint covered by the Dark Energy Survey (DES) DR1 (The Dark Energy Survey Collaboration et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), and present new lens candidates. Our choice is motivated by three criteria: the DES-DR1 release is public, which ensures reproducibility; its footprint lies mostly in the South, which is still largely unexplored; and the sheer convenience of display from the NCSA DESaccess cut-out service,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup> which enabled a swift visual inspection of image cut-outs. Magnitudes <em>W</em>1, <em>W</em>2, <em>W</em>3 from the <em>Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer</em> (hereafter <em>WISE</em>; Wright et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) and from the <em>Gaia</em> space mission (Gaia Collaboration et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) are given in their native Vega system.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The paper is organized as follows. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, we describe each of the search methods, and its possible biases. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>, we estimate the performance of each method, in terms of known lens recovery and of new candidates produced over the DES-DR1 footprint. We also provide tables of candidates, to facilitate spectroscopic follow-up, including at least two \u2018new\u2019 quadruplets: WG\u00a0210014.9-445206.4 and WG\u00a0021416.37-210535.3 (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). We conclude in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"157796223\" scrollto-destination=\"157796223\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/489/2/10.1093_mnras_stz2200/2/m_stz2200fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611464883&amp;Signature=LAAPiEizxraPd24mz92PBXQzk44NMpBJEsk4ldj-ZDOsTvCnlbmvdBuHKapkgzRsqupJ4l33fG8QUUYqXOJAY6OZ~G1OqZHFhrk26~WaLtDoewYlTlYo29CdEwdB82w1bHStKqSogUtegBUlRfWeTZhONvzukb6~3a8vTXPtbiUx1iOiwm8WlbDC5wd-Obwzmn4k9nbWpjL2O57bou0FUUe4h-ymKjcf~O5r71Zcv3ebn-~qb~54aIg4ZX1kc5Sxa-mSNYeBJYyQ9DoJFqvdVAfRHatA9sqQAF5NBKmvXEEO-ju199nlkPO-L~BgABSoWLa~~kcdFWCgYZkDD~ruow__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The nine quadruplets found by at least one method in the DES public footprint, with WISE extragalactic colours. Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> gives references for all quadruplets.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/489/2/10.1093_mnras_stz2200/2/m_stz2200fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611464883&amp;Signature=LAAPiEizxraPd24mz92PBXQzk44NMpBJEsk4ldj-ZDOsTvCnlbmvdBuHKapkgzRsqupJ4l33fG8QUUYqXOJAY6OZ~G1OqZHFhrk26~WaLtDoewYlTlYo29CdEwdB82w1bHStKqSogUtegBUlRfWeTZhONvzukb6~3a8vTXPtbiUx1iOiwm8WlbDC5wd-Obwzmn4k9nbWpjL2O57bou0FUUe4h-ymKjcf~O5r71Zcv3ebn-~qb~54aIg4ZX1kc5Sxa-mSNYeBJYyQ9DoJFqvdVAfRHatA9sqQAF5NBKmvXEEO-ju199nlkPO-L~BgABSoWLa~~kcdFWCgYZkDD~ruow__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The nine quadruplets found by at least one method in the DES public footprint, with WISE extragalactic colours. The 11.5\u00a0arcsec\u00a0\u00d7 11.5\u00a0arcsec cut-outs are obtained from the DES Data Access page, and are shown in DES <em>gri</em> bands. WG\u00a02100-4452 is a previously unknown quad, and the discovery of WG\u00a00214-2105 has been recently reported by Agnello (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>, RNAAS). WG\u00a0J0053-2012 and WG\u00a00405-33 have been found independently in STRIDES (Anguita et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_62_1567401739549\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_62_1567401739549\" data-open=\"bib1_62_1567401739549\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Schechter\u00a0&amp; Treu, private communication). Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> gives references for all quadruplets.</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=157796224 id=\"157796224\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 THE METHODS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We use five different methods, of which two are mostly morphological and rely on <em>Gaia</em> multiplet detection or chromatic offsets; one is based on spectroscopic pre-selection from fibre-spectroscopic surveys; and two are based on radio and X-ray pre-selection</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The searches are structured similarly: a first step of <em>object pre-selection</em>, based on shallow cuts on catalogue magnitudes and colours; a second step of <em>target</em> selection, still based on catalogue entries; and a final step of <em>candidate</em> selection, through visual inspection of image cut-outs. For the sake of convenience, the DES-DR1 public cut-out service was used. However, in its current version, it properly displays between 50\u00a0per\u2009cent and 70\u00a0per\u2009cent of the cut-outs that are produced due to software issues.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a></sup> For this reason, the final numbers of candidates given in this paper should be taken as purely indicative, and a significant number of quasar lenses may still be found among the systems that were not properly displayed.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In what follows, the general performance on known systems is evaluated using a <em>benchmark</em> list of 214 known quasar lenses and pairs, collated from the CASTLES and SQLS (Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) data bases, consistently with previous work (Williams et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). When restricting to the DES footprint, we will also consider lenses that have been found more recently through different endeavours (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"157796228\" scrollto-destination=\"157796228\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Known lenses in the DES-DR1 public footprint recovered by the different search methods of Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>. Magnitudes are from <em>WISE</em> and <em>Gaia</em>-DR1 and given in the Vega system. The first six systems in the table are the known quadruplets, whose cut-outs are also shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. Here, W2MG1 denotes 2MASS-versus-<em>Gaia</em> chromatic offsets (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.1</a>), and \u2018mult\u2019 or \u2018sing\u2019 marks objects that correspond to <em>Gaia</em> multiplets or singlets, respectively.</p></div> </div><div (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3_212_1567692831961\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3_212_1567692831961\" data-open=\"bib3_212_1567692831961\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J202139.38\u2212411557.9\u00a0</td><td>14.17\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>13.17\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>10.44\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.07\u00a0</td><td>19.27\u00a0</td><td>W2MG1mult, GaiaDR2mult\u00a0</td><td>Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>)\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>object<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>W</em>1<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>W</em>2<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>W</em>3<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>G</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Methods<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Reference<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>J005344.44\u2212201233.7\u00a0</td><td>14.56\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>14.01\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04\u00a0</td><td>10.76\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.10\u00a0</td><td>19.21\u00a0</td><td>GaiaDR2mult\u00a0</td><td>STRIDES (in preparation)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J021416.37\u2212210535.3\u00a0</td><td>15.11\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>14.68\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.06\u00a0</td><td>11.82\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.24\u00a0</td><td>19.80\u00a0</td><td>GaiaDR2mult\u00a0</td><td>Agnello (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>, RNAAS)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J023233.16\u2212211725.7\u00a0</td><td>14.02\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>12.99\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>10.06\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.05\u00a0</td><td>18.93\u00a0</td><td>XMMslew\u00a0</td><td>Wisotzki et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J025942.86\u2212163543.0\u00a0</td><td>13.86\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>13.13\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>10.03\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.05\u00a0</td><td>19.22\u00a0</td><td>W2MG1sing\u00a0</td><td>Schechter et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J040559.76\u2212330851.0\u00a0</td><td>13.85\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>12.71\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02\u00a0</td><td>9.94\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04\u00a0</td><td>20.22\u00a0</td><td>W2MG1mult, GaiaDR2mult\u00a0</td><td>Anguita et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J023527.42\u2212243313.8\u00a0</td><td>14.00\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>13.02\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>10.29\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.05\u00a0</td><td>18.12\u00a0</td><td>W2MG1mult, GaiaDR2mult\u00a0</td><td>Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J051410.90\u2212332622.4\u00a0</td><td>13.29\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>11.71\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02\u00a0</td><td>8.54\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02\u00a0</td><td>17.80\u00a0</td><td>HE, RASS\u00a0</td><td>Gregg et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3_212_1567692831961\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3_212_1567692831961\" data-open=\"bib3_212_1567692831961\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J202139.38\u2212411557.9\u00a0</td><td>14.17\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>13.17\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>10.44\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.07\u00a0</td><td>19.27\u00a0</td><td>W2MG1mult, GaiaDR2mult\u00a0</td><td>Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>)\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/157796228\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=157796229 id=\"157796229\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 BaROQuES: blue and red offsets of quasars and extragalactic sources</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Here, we exploit observations of the same objects across different surveys, under the hypothesis that lenses can show astrometric offsets (across surveys with different waveband coverage, or depth, or image quality) due to the presence of different components. This enables a catalogue-based selection of composite objects regardless of blending issues, before examining the image cutouts.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The <em>Gaia</em> mission had \u22482\u00a0arcsec image resolution in DR1 and \u22480.5\u00a0arcsec in DR2, which enables the recognition of multiple images in lensed quasars that are otherwise not deblended by the image-processing pipelines of ground-based surveys. The search of quasar lenses in DES through <em>Gaia</em>-DR1 multiplet recognition has already been made within STRIDES (Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>). However, not all known lenses are deblended into multiple <span class=\"monospace\">source</span> entries in <em>Gaia</em>-DR1 (e.g. Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>). For this reason, we need complementary techniques to cope with incomplete deblending, in order to maximize completeness on lens searches.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For systems that are not <em>Gaia</em> multiplets, we can still use the accurate astrometry of <em>Gaia</em> to compare shifts in image centroids among different surveys. To this aim, we consider objects that are bright enough to have positions in the 2-Micron All-Sky Survey (2MASS) catalogue, and consider their 2MASS-<em>Gaia</em> offsets. Matters are slightly complicated, due to atmospheric differential refraction (ADR) and the choice of astrometric calibrators for each survey. Recent searches based on chromatic offsets (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) relied on SDSS-versus-<em>Gaia</em> solutions, calibrated on astrometric reference stars, and had abundant contamination from isolated (unlensed) quasars. This is due to the different colours of quasars and astrometric stars, which can result in \u22480.3\u00a0arcsec offsets due to ADR (with typical \u224820\u00a0deg zenith angles of ground-based surveys).</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We resolve this by means of field-corrected offsets, using our own BaROQuES scripts,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">3</a></sup> as follows. First, we work with a sample of quasar-like objects, selected in <em>WISE</em> as<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">4</a></sup><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nW1-W2\\gt 0.35-\\sqrt{(\\delta W1)^{2}+(\\delta W2)^{2}},\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}\r\n$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ2\" content-id=\"equ2\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nW1-W2\\gt 0.2+\\sqrt{(\\delta W1)^{2}+(\\delta W2)^{2}},\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}\r\n$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(2)</span></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ3\" content-id=\"equ3\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nW2-W3\\gt 2.1+\\sqrt{(\\delta W2)^{2}+(\\delta W3)^{2}},\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}\r\n$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(3)</span></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ4\" content-id=\"equ4\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nW1\\lt 17, W2\\lt 15.6, W3\\lt 11.8.\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}\r\n$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(4)</span></div>Then, for each given object we examine a surrounding patch of 1.0\u00a0\u00d7\u00a01.0\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup>, containing \u224840 QSO-like neighbours. We then compute the average offsets between their 2MASS and <em>Gaia</em> coordinates \u03b4<em>x</em>\u00a0= \u2212cos\u2009(Dec.)\u03b4RA, \u03b4<em>y</em>\u00a0= \u03b4Dec., subtract them from the offsets of the given object, and retain it only if this corrected offset is between 0.27 and 1.8\u00a0arcsec. This ensures that known lenses are recovered, and chance alignments of quasars with other objects are safely rejected. The lower threshold in separation is chosen because the root-mean-square (field-corrected) offsets of isolated objects can be up to 0.2\u20130.3\u00a0arcsec in each patch.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">When applied to the Southern Galactic hemisphere, with <em>b</em> &lt; \u221220 and \u221270 &lt; Dec. &lt; 7, this gave \u22486\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>4</sup> objects, of which 31\u00a0381 singlets and 770 multiplets in the DES-DR1 footprint.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=157796235 id=\"157796235\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 <em>Gaia</em>-DR2 multiplets</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The nominal resolution of <em>Gaia</em> has improved from 2\u00a0arcsec (DR1) to 0.4\u00a0arcsec (DR2), so a simple upgrade consists in searching again for <em>Gaia</em>-DR2 multiplets corresponding to <em>WISE</em> sources. There is indeed some improvement from DR1 to DR2: out of the \u22486\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>4</sup><em>Gaia</em>-DR1 singlet \u2018BaROQuES\u2019 from above, a match with DR2 gave 2149 multiplets, of which 134 with more than two <span class=\"monospace\">source</span> entries.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">However, some candidates and small-separation lenses from DR1 have disappeared in the passage to DR2 (e.g. WGD0508; Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>). The same has been noticed by Spiniello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) on a smaller footprint (KiDS-DR3, 450\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup>). In general, the <em>Gaia</em>-specific deblending does not seem to have a well-defined behaviour with separation and flux ratios, as some small-separation lenses are recognized as multiplets while larger-separation lenses correspond to <em>Gaia</em> singlets (e.g. WGD0150, WGD0245; Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>).</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">In order to make additional progress over the searches in <em>Gaia</em>-DR1, we also relaxed the pre-selection photometric criteria. From a <em>WISE</em> search, we selected extragalactic objects as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"update217119_equ5\" content-id=\"update217119_equ5\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nW1-W2\\,\\gt\\, 0.2+\\sqrt{(\\delta W1)^{2}+(\\delta W2)^{2}},\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}\r\n$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(5)</span></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ6\" content-id=\"equ6\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nW1\\lt 17, W3\\lt 12.4\\\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}\r\n$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(6)</span></div>basically excluding stars (<em>W</em>1 \u2212 <em>W</em>2 \u2248 0) and fainter objects with unreliable catalogue magnitudes. This gave <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {O}(10^6)$|</span> objects with Galactic latitude <em>b</em> &lt; \u221215. Of these, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {O}(10^5)$|</span> are recognized as multiplets in <em>Gaia</em>-DR2.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn5\" data-open=\"fn5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">5</a></sup> However, many are clustered towards the Galactic disc and the Magellanic Clouds, which can be explained with the line-of-sight alignment of quasars with stars. In order to exclude most quasar-star pair contaminants, we then impose a threshold on the ratio \u03a3<sub>m</sub>/\u03a3<sub>s</sub>, between densities of multiplets (\u03a3<sub>m</sub>) and singlets (\u03a3<sub>s</sub>), estimated in 0.5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a00.5\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> patches around each multiplet.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn6\" data-open=\"fn6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">6</a></sup> For the <em>Gaia</em> doubles, we retain only objects in regions where \u03a3<sub>m</sub>/\u03a3<sub>s</sub> &lt; 0.2; for <em>Gaia</em> triplets and quadruplets, we relax it to \u03a3<sub>m</sub>/\u03a3<sub>s</sub> &lt; 0.3. After the overdensity threshold cuts, \u224817\u00a0000 multiplets remain, of which 8146 lie in the DES-DR1 public footprint.</div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=157796239 id=\"157796239\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-3>2.3 Spectroscopic surveys</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Some of the longest known quasar lenses, such as e.g. Q0957+561 (Walsh, Carswell\u00a0&amp; Weymann <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1979</a>) and lenses from the Hamburg-ESO survey (Wisotzki et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>), were found in wide-field, prism spectroscopic surveys. Over the last decade, searches in the SDSS and BOSS (Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) relied on samples of objects that were classified as quasar based on fibre spectroscopy. Also, some lenses recently found in the DES (Ostrovski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>) had pre-existing fibre spectra in the Anglo-Australian Observatory data bases, where they had been targeted as quasars or galaxies and not recognized as lenses, due to low image resolution.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For this reason, we examined two surveys with moderate depth and uniform coverage over large areas in the Southern hemisphere: the six-degree field galaxy survey (6dFGS; Jones et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) and the 2QZ (Boyle et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>). These two surveys were also based on different pre-selection cuts, based on optical cuts in all-sky surveys of moderate depth, focusing on galaxy-like (6dFGS) or quasar-like (2QZ) objects. In this sense, then, they are also complementary to the <em>WISE</em> criteria that we have used in our photometric searches.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We restrict these samples to objects with<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn7\" data-open=\"fn7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">7</a></sup><em>pipeline redshifts z</em><sub>s</sub> &gt; 0.5, as expected from simulated samples (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a>) and our benchmark of CASTLES/SQLS known lenses. This gave 1625 objects from the 6dFGS and 7147 from 2QZ, over the DES footprint. Due to the different choices in optical colour pre-selection of the 6dFGS and 2QZ, there is no overlap between the candidate samples from these two surveys.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=157796243 id=\"157796243\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-4>2.4 X-Ray</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Quasars can also be identified by X-ray emission, due to lower dust attenuation in that spectral range. The recently vetted cross-match (Salvato et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) the <em>ROSAT</em> all-sky survey (Boller et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) and XMMslew survey (Georgakakis\u00a0&amp; Nandra <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) with <em>WISE</em> then provides an alternative pre-selection of possible candidates. Some lenses discovered in <em>ROSAT</em> are indeed known, such as RXJ0911.4+0551 (Bade et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>), RXJ0921+4529 (Mu\u00f1oz et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>), and RXJ1131\u22121231 (Sluse et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>). A fainter lens, CY2201\u22123201 (Castander et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) was found in the <em>Chandra</em> deep fields.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We then used the publicly available cross-match tables<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn8\" data-open=\"fn8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">8</a></sup> to pre-select X-ray objects. Also in this search, we excluded possible stars with the same cuts as above (equations\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-update217119_equ5\"></span><a href=\"#update217119_equ5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ6\"></span><a href=\"#equ6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6</a>). This yielded 13\u00a0547 cut-outs from <em>ROSAT</em>\u2013<em>WISE</em> and 2294 from <em>XMM</em>\u2013<em>WISE</em>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=157796246 id=\"157796246\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-5>2.5 Radio</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Similarly to X-ray pre-selection, radio searches are less affected by reddening and by the presence of a foreground galaxy. As a consequence, they bypass the colour selection that can affect optical or IR searches. Indeed, quasar lens discoveries in the past have benefited from hemispheric surveys like the Parkes-MIT-NRAO survey (Griffith\u00a0&amp; Wright <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1993</a>) and dedicated observations by the CLASS (Myers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) and J-VLA (King et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>) searches.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Here, we use the Sydney University Molonglo Sky Survey (SUMSS; Mauch et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>), covering the Southern hemisphere down to \u224810\u00a0mJy at 0.84\u00a0GHz. We match the catalogue with <em>WISE</em>, using a nearest-neighbour match with 10\u00a0arcsec search radius, and retained extragalactic objects as above (equations\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-update217119_equ5\"></span><a href=\"#update217119_equ5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ6\"></span><a href=\"#equ6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6</a>). This resulted in 38\u00a0204 cut-outs within the DES-DR1 footprint.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=157796249 id=\"157796249\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 PERFORMANCE AND RESULTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The performance of each method can be quantified in different ways. One metric is given by completeness and purity with respect to previous searches. Another possibility is the number of candidates that are produced by each method over the same footprint. The final evaluation of performance is the purity of the candidate samples, once spectroscopic follow-up is performed. Most of the candidates presented in this paper are still awaiting spectroscopic confirmation, and published samples of lenses and contaminants over the DES footprint are still too small to build robust statistics. Then for the scope of this paper, we discuss the recovery of known lenses over DES-DR1, and properties of candidate samples from different searches. We also provide estimates of completeness and purity, based on the expected fraction of quadruplets. These are in line with findings of ongoing spectroscopic campaigns (Spiniello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=157796251 id=\"157796251\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 Known lenses and the DES subsample</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> lists the known lenses recovered over the DES-DR1 footprint. Five lenses are two image systems, and eight are (at least) quadruplets. Two of them (WG\u00a00405-3308 and WG\u00a00053-2012) have also been found, independently, within the STRIDES collaboration (Anguita et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_62_1567401739549\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_62_1567401739549\" data-open=\"bib1_62_1567401739549\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Schechter\u00a0&amp; Treu, private communication). The discovery of WG\u00a00214-2105 has been recently reported by Agnello (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). The two \u2018new\u2019 quad candidates, WG\u00a02100-4452 and WG\u00a00214-2105, have just recently been confirmed spectroscopically, and have been shown to be well reproducible by simple lens models (Wynne\u00a0&amp; Schechter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The recovery statistics of known lenses in <em>Gaia</em>-DR2 is slightly better than for <em>Gaia</em>-DR1 (e.g. Agnello <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). We quantify this through the <em>benchmark</em> list of 214 CASTLES/SQLS systems introduced in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>. Of these, 43 are missing from <em>Gaia</em>-DR2. Of the 171 that are detected, 124 are resolved in two sources, 15 into three sources, and 6 into four sources. Small-separation lenses are absent in <em>Gaia</em>-DR2, because of a sharper cut-off at \u22480.5\u00a0arcsec separations in the DR2 catalogue. These include also systems that were found thanks to <em>Gaia</em>-DR1 (e.g. WGD\u00a00508; Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=157796254 id=\"157796254\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 Candidates</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Visual inspection of targets from the above methods resulted in 16 BaROQuES in <em>Gaia</em>-DR1 versus 2MASS (not counting WG0214, already reported, see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>), of which 5 <em>Gaia</em> multiplets; 20 candidates from <em>Gaia</em>-DR2 multiplets (including WG2100, reported here for the first time); 7 candidates from fibre-spectroscopy (3 from 6dFGS and 4 from 2QZ); 29 candidates from X-ray pre-selection, of which 28 from <em>ROSAT</em>; and 26 candidates from SUMSS. The full lists of high-graded candidates are provided in Tables\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A2</a>, divided by search method. We list their names (J2000 coordinates), as well as their <em>WISE</em> (<em>W</em>1, <em>W</em>2, <em>W</em>3) and <em>Gaia</em>-DR1 (<em>G</em>) magnitudes. These total to 98 unique candidates.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The number of targets and candidates per square degree from each search depends on its depth and design. Searches relying on SUMSS, <em>ROSAT</em>, 2MASS, and <em>Gaia</em> resulted in comparable numbers of candidates (modulo the depth limits of each survey). The search based on the 6dFGS, while nominally using a hemispheric survey, resulted in much fewer candidates, because the catalogue objects themselves had been selected as nearby galaxy candidates based on their optical colours.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> shows the colour and magnitude distributions of the candidates. Different colours and markers represent the different methods through which the candidates have been identified. Known lenses are plotted in red (dashed in the magnitude histograms, triangles in the colour\u2013colour plot). <em>Gaia</em>-selected candidates extend the regime of known lenses towards fainter magnitudes, still with a cut-off at the faint end due to noisy <em>WISE</em> magnitudes and the drop in <em>Gaia</em> completeness at <em>G</em> \u2248 20. X-ray and radio-selected candidates populate the faint end of the magnitude distribution, with few objects corresponding to optical detections in <em>Gaia</em> (26 of these objects are missed by <em>Gaia</em> DR1 and/or DR2).</p>                        <a id=\"157796258\" scrollto-destination=\"157796258\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/489/2/10.1093_mnras_stz2200/2/m_stz2200fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611464883&amp;Signature=XCqL1UBvImyxfJKgQj9XGolPUSf4EVAILlu46Z91EK05lF7WFz8YTlSbus37679YyfBpAsm53r8sTYguwPMMRlK5ujHtOwrPiUbcRYzRRu7uxBoHq-jWfnH0xZ75R70gDWOrsXWHnHYWiWli85GyRsxJkY9HQrqj9b-uu3A5aZKYN4AISF9HIWcmGUCpoMZPZvpuyhixsZZaDW6wA2f3t3ZdEFbAJ9moZqeY~Y1udO2cZ8jECGcBZ3RY6B7r5qW7vxzRItFrZ03v8Tv6FtbiTrrbp002mYGyWXrMme-R1D26g5lmIpXQJl9IsidLUVi4T4LZsCgoCmUh1kQ94goZgg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Magnitude and colour distributions of candidates and known lenses. Middle: G \u2212magnitude distribution, with the same colour coding. Right: colours W1 \u2212 W2 versus W2 \u2212 W3, same colour coding (and markers) as in the first panel. We have added WG\u00a02100-4452 to the sample of \u2018known\u2019 quadruplets, instead of showing it separately. BaROQueS and Multiplets are grouped, because they are based on Gaia. Red triangles represent the known lenses recovered by the five searches.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/157796258/stz2200fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"157796258\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/489/2/10.1093_mnras_stz2200/2/stz2200fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611464883&Signature=vnQYwMHzcsZjHPeGsrk0Kq-BH0V2Z7RmFeitS9mUVm0~GaGfW2GwS7kHoGUOJy16nfuegFw9PeSqci5OplTJ2TaLpzLTYOGfB~7BB1qzTx5UzXXacv1kRzC7ECuD0VN91SvqOLrL-~MoLlnez3L-w~as7vYsig3~or~4Qhih9mkA6z1Ka2TjeCdtdznj1Quhln0PYkaI0~jmRtVGpz10AA5JODoNQyIdUZCVbAOviMrMBaMFr8uoHNGRuyEQukRxqxVN5-Nb1Iw5doQ1N~W30rM6cSucdNSZ5u1xGAfxnqz~EEjOobLPvGbeYv52NNkd0NisBfOxxbB9p8F8xLO8ng__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=157796258&ar=5548822&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Magnitude and colour distributions of candidates and known lenses. <em>Left: W</em>1 \u2212 magnitude distribution for <em>Gaia</em> candidates (blue), radio candidates (orange, dotted), X-ray candidates (green, dot\u2013dashed) and known lenses (red, dashed), truncated to the <em>WISE</em> completeness limit <em>W</em>1\u00a0=\u00a017. <em>Middle: G</em> \u2212magnitude distribution, with the same colour coding. <em>Right:</em> colours <em>W</em>1 \u2212 <em>W</em>2 versus <em>W</em>2 \u2212 <em>W</em>3, same colour coding (and markers) as in the first panel. We have added WG\u00a02100-4452 to the sample of \u2018known\u2019 quadruplets, instead of showing it separately. BaROQueS and Multiplets are grouped, because they are based on <em>Gaia</em>. Red triangles represent the known lenses recovered by the five searches.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/489/2/10.1093_mnras_stz2200/2/m_stz2200fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611464883&amp;Signature=XCqL1UBvImyxfJKgQj9XGolPUSf4EVAILlu46Z91EK05lF7WFz8YTlSbus37679YyfBpAsm53r8sTYguwPMMRlK5ujHtOwrPiUbcRYzRRu7uxBoHq-jWfnH0xZ75R70gDWOrsXWHnHYWiWli85GyRsxJkY9HQrqj9b-uu3A5aZKYN4AISF9HIWcmGUCpoMZPZvpuyhixsZZaDW6wA2f3t3ZdEFbAJ9moZqeY~Y1udO2cZ8jECGcBZ3RY6B7r5qW7vxzRItFrZ03v8Tv6FtbiTrrbp002mYGyWXrMme-R1D26g5lmIpXQJl9IsidLUVi4T4LZsCgoCmUh1kQ94goZgg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Magnitude and colour distributions of candidates and known lenses. Left: W1 \u2212 magnitude distribution for Gaia candidates (blue), radio candidates (orange, dotted), X-ray candidates (green, dot\u2013dashed) and known lenses (red, dashed), truncated to the WISE completeness limit W1\u00a0=\u00a017. Middle: G \u2212magnitude distribution, with the same colour coding. Right: colours W1 \u2212 W2 versus W2 \u2212 W3, same colour coding (and markers) as in the first panel. We have added WG\u00a02100-4452 to the sample of \u2018known\u2019 quadruplets, instead of showing it separately. BaROQueS and Multiplets are grouped, because they are based on Gaia. Red triangles represent the known lenses recovered by the five searches.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/157796258/stz2200fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"157796258\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/489/2/10.1093_mnras_stz2200/2/stz2200fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611464883&Signature=vnQYwMHzcsZjHPeGsrk0Kq-BH0V2Z7RmFeitS9mUVm0~GaGfW2GwS7kHoGUOJy16nfuegFw9PeSqci5OplTJ2TaLpzLTYOGfB~7BB1qzTx5UzXXacv1kRzC7ECuD0VN91SvqOLrL-~MoLlnez3L-w~as7vYsig3~or~4Qhih9mkA6z1Ka2TjeCdtdznj1Quhln0PYkaI0~jmRtVGpz10AA5JODoNQyIdUZCVbAOviMrMBaMFr8uoHNGRuyEQukRxqxVN5-Nb1Iw5doQ1N~W30rM6cSucdNSZ5u1xGAfxnqz~EEjOobLPvGbeYv52NNkd0NisBfOxxbB9p8F8xLO8ng__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=157796258&ar=5548822&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Magnitude and colour distributions of candidates and known lenses. <em>Left: W</em>1 \u2212 magnitude distribution for <em>Gaia</em> candidates (blue), radio candidates (orange, dotted), X-ray candidates (green, dot\u2013dashed) and known lenses (red, dashed), truncated to the <em>WISE</em> completeness limit <em>W</em>1\u00a0=\u00a017. <em>Middle: G</em> \u2212magnitude distribution, with the same colour coding. <em>Right:</em> colours <em>W</em>1 \u2212 <em>W</em>2 versus <em>W</em>2 \u2212 <em>W</em>3, same colour coding (and markers) as in the first panel. We have added WG\u00a02100-4452 to the sample of \u2018known\u2019 quadruplets, instead of showing it separately. BaROQueS and Multiplets are grouped, because they are based on <em>Gaia</em>. Red triangles represent the known lenses recovered by the five searches.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Two main clusters of systems are visible in the <em>WISE</em> colour\u2013colour plot: objects with high <em>W</em>1 \u2212 <em>W</em>2, compatible with QSO-dominated photometry, and systems with lower <em>W</em>1 \u2212 <em>W</em>2, compatible with galaxy-dominated photometry. Systems with low <em>W</em>1 \u2212 <em>W</em>2 (left-most panel) mostly have <em>W</em>3 \u226511.8, which is the threshold where <em>WISE</em> magnitudes become unreliable. There is a prevalence of radio-selected objects in the galaxy-dominated clump, whereas X-ray and <em>Gaia</em>-selected systems are evenly distributed. Known lenses are mostly associated with the QSO-dominated regime.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Candidates selected from each method are shown in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. All methods produce sensible results upon visual inspection, albeit with a pre-dominance of high-grade candidates from the<em>Gaia</em> searches. Some candidates (mostly from SUMMS and spectroscopic surveys) may be lenses with bright deflectors, or mergers of compact narrow-line galaxies at lower redshift. With the depth (<em>i</em> \u2248 22.5) and image resolution of Pan-STARRS and DES-DR1 (\u22480.26\u00a0arcsec\u00a0pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>, \u22481\u00a0arcsec seeing), these contaminants are still present in candidate samples.</p>                        <a id=\"157796261\" scrollto-destination=\"157796261\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/489/2/10.1093_mnras_stz2200/2/m_stz2200fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611464883&amp;Signature=Z7csyyZPt9KRhiiQSMqGTzUw1v8R4dfzQ03kmKvwUH-FVZXtEQEKLRD0WMMy7p-F5hPnWofSzyUj5r9fnjSV~Uo7JWX9xRYd2rwZZPFErJeZFG-B~ePGDLdstyGyqWaNDL4e-OBjCN1UO-AKESGo0THo7L0pzRESyTuhqVut-SdS06HNxNtjEy6uT2KEJ67B8Ud~cKN7ZtvIiBYlaf4J1gqwOFpSqf0AkYHZu3iI2Ti9JGLy8g8L91LYmfp-Lfz-CXb1hLZjakf-Dm9Jz6A~iGwC8Z8lluNRKNeSSNTvRO~gD1KNb-k1dc8Ql4srKSXlOEtisKmzD7kLCWm0T8bAXg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Examples of candidates found in Gaia DR1 and DR2, with WISE pre-selection (same colour scheme as in Fig.\u00a01). W2MG1 denotes WISE objects with acceptable offsets between their 2MASS and Gaia-DR1 catalogue positions, with recomputed astrometry from our BaROQuES scripts.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/157796261/stz2200fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"157796261\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/489/2/10.1093_mnras_stz2200/2/stz2200fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611464883&Signature=tbF3Bfgr1aoVI4w7jEs-OhSn~Y5OixY5F4IT8aih8TrDrz1dwQkL9-zLg0G5aFyUE14B-VaLgwR~zP~9CpcNMFLTHnzuWhmgqpATgKUqAs9e3~nA6LXZIXQgnroKeOsxWRHfHXPJIJYhdnRP1J98oYv0hkhQx5uoF4v3KL2xDonoxDbpnTItzmlRRC3diw5fqT8yQZYP3PW-8HFqoFCBdv6AzTuGsgBcj7l1i9Cge2KZ6asFkbCDaY5tOlKZnfyQ0Vy4FhP9QvLqS2Ft3Dy--WxH8c~RYJSikbEQxi6HF1QTGEIVRRQCft957kz1mTqXV5TlZj3JkFveYAmgJ8mvyw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=157796261&ar=5548822&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Examples of candidates found in <em>Gaia</em> DR1 and DR2, with <em>WISE</em> pre-selection (same colour scheme as in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). W2MG1 denotes <em>WISE</em> objects with acceptable offsets between their 2MASS and <em>Gaia</em>-DR1 catalogue positions, with recomputed astrometry from our BaROQuES scripts.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/489/2/10.1093_mnras_stz2200/2/m_stz2200fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611464883&amp;Signature=Z7csyyZPt9KRhiiQSMqGTzUw1v8R4dfzQ03kmKvwUH-FVZXtEQEKLRD0WMMy7p-F5hPnWofSzyUj5r9fnjSV~Uo7JWX9xRYd2rwZZPFErJeZFG-B~ePGDLdstyGyqWaNDL4e-OBjCN1UO-AKESGo0THo7L0pzRESyTuhqVut-SdS06HNxNtjEy6uT2KEJ67B8Ud~cKN7ZtvIiBYlaf4J1gqwOFpSqf0AkYHZu3iI2Ti9JGLy8g8L91LYmfp-Lfz-CXb1hLZjakf-Dm9Jz6A~iGwC8Z8lluNRKNeSSNTvRO~gD1KNb-k1dc8Ql4srKSXlOEtisKmzD7kLCWm0T8bAXg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Examples of candidates found in Gaia DR1 and DR2, with WISE pre-selection (same colour scheme as in Fig.\u00a01). W2MG1 denotes WISE objects with acceptable offsets between their 2MASS and Gaia-DR1 catalogue positions, with recomputed astrometry from our BaROQuES scripts.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/157796261/stz2200fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"157796261\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/489/2/10.1093_mnras_stz2200/2/stz2200fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611464883&Signature=tbF3Bfgr1aoVI4w7jEs-OhSn~Y5OixY5F4IT8aih8TrDrz1dwQkL9-zLg0G5aFyUE14B-VaLgwR~zP~9CpcNMFLTHnzuWhmgqpATgKUqAs9e3~nA6LXZIXQgnroKeOsxWRHfHXPJIJYhdnRP1J98oYv0hkhQx5uoF4v3KL2xDonoxDbpnTItzmlRRC3diw5fqT8yQZYP3PW-8HFqoFCBdv6AzTuGsgBcj7l1i9Cge2KZ6asFkbCDaY5tOlKZnfyQ0Vy4FhP9QvLqS2Ft3Dy--WxH8c~RYJSikbEQxi6HF1QTGEIVRRQCft957kz1mTqXV5TlZj3JkFveYAmgJ8mvyw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=157796261&ar=5548822&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Examples of candidates found in <em>Gaia</em> DR1 and DR2, with <em>WISE</em> pre-selection (same colour scheme as in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). W2MG1 denotes <em>WISE</em> objects with acceptable offsets between their 2MASS and <em>Gaia</em>-DR1 catalogue positions, with recomputed astrometry from our BaROQuES scripts.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"157796262\" scrollto-destination=\"157796262\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" alt=\"Examples of candidates found with spectroscopic (2QZ, 6dFGS), radio (SUMMS), or X-ray (ROSAT, XMMslew) surveys.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig
