tab</a><a data-section=\"157796262\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/489/2/10.1093_mnras_stz2200/2/stz2200fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611464883&Signature=kD3PbpGpwl~IFhIiZCInh5UfuUOh8PI0DTMe9HF6PF0Ez5NSXzqAqJnFJ7nhVABA1oPnl4ficB4sWnDP4HbLZTwwlGfenpjEACjZGl8xi48HArPgDElBQeFnykJ8u0V0qhsgr-7DTbMLWCsCdPfmCYh2clSmDu00A5LwcZV~FckLVctSJXL-GC1WDpIPAsDcbkc6fNOE2OoUTufIELpVpEm~G3NOG4KuaBCh1DuqVpIUFIIE~HQHq3LUl4Pn1mvvueC6aERSTJas25P5Dfv61uGm~HI4XNZWLz4Zpol56X6gYPsap7rLGyNFKqFFctN5oZb9~mJsGdMLrK6q2PDitA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=157796262&ar=5548822&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Examples of candidates found with spectroscopic (2QZ, 6dFGS), radio (SUMMS), or X-ray (<em>ROSAT</em>, XMMslew) surveys.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/489/2/10.1093_mnras_stz2200/2/m_stz2200fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611464883&amp;Signature=NNyCHHqj7cligPENbSFa~1gc8IY0XuCmaEkSXgwS8Lqy1zrOb-JxUObbaem19bRJMO6JBArcUowrdtiwLWx30-1flrv97kAFwlPFvtcqZphWDSUIPQ5JogPemBit8qJ19YgpWhFO2F4E7GfMuqUQWnjSsiLUN-mM41K2~q9Df6REPlpg8SdihLlI5zpDTEWzqAPp6JJppqDJ~oncyEQor-xwe9KHVh25odox~MTK7Zxqw6TqOJyFLav~fLvuXEZzQCt9ZygnEZOZd-8IcptOaTxqGF3r67suMFymIPbTf~jTF6aM41nkqiMwW4SXVBsp~kctiyLvIzJLS9Fkx2wLag__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Examples of candidates found with spectroscopic (2QZ, 6dFGS), radio (SUMMS), or X-ray (ROSAT, XMMslew) surveys.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/157796262/stz2200fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"157796262\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/489/2/10.1093_mnras_stz2200/2/stz2200fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611464883&Signature=kD3PbpGpwl~IFhIiZCInh5UfuUOh8PI0DTMe9HF6PF0Ez5NSXzqAqJnFJ7nhVABA1oPnl4ficB4sWnDP4HbLZTwwlGfenpjEACjZGl8xi48HArPgDElBQeFnykJ8u0V0qhsgr-7DTbMLWCsCdPfmCYh2clSmDu00A5LwcZV~FckLVctSJXL-GC1WDpIPAsDcbkc6fNOE2OoUTufIELpVpEm~G3NOG4KuaBCh1DuqVpIUFIIE~HQHq3LUl4Pn1mvvueC6aERSTJas25P5Dfv61uGm~HI4XNZWLz4Zpol56X6gYPsap7rLGyNFKqFFctN5oZb9~mJsGdMLrK6q2PDitA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=157796262&ar=5548822&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Examples of candidates found with spectroscopic (2QZ, 6dFGS), radio (SUMMS), or X-ray (<em>ROSAT</em>, XMMslew) surveys.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Visual inspection is a critical step in candidate selection. Quadruplets are often clear to recognize, especially after some simple, model-based scoring (e.g. Wynne\u00a0&amp; Schechter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Doubles, on the other hand, are less obvious: contaminants include physical or line-of-sight pairs of quasars; line-of-sight pairs of quasars and stars or galaxies; pairs of compact narrow-line galaxies; and galaxies seen through two stars. Some <em>nearly identical</em> quasar pairs (or NIQs; Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>) may actually be lenses whose deflector is too faint to be detected in ground-based discovery data, especially at small separations (as discussed e.g. by Morgan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>). High-grade candidate doubles were then selected based on whether the putative quasar images had same colours, and whether a candidate deflector galaxy was visible in between, for image-separations larger than \u22481.5\u00a0times the seeing.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=157796264 id=\"157796264\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>3.3 Quadruplets</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Due to their higher number of images, with respect to doubles, quadruplets yield more constraints on the deflector potential and stellar mass fraction, and for this reason, they are especially valued probes of cosmography (e.g. Refsdal <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1964</a>; Blandford\u00a0&amp; Narayan <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>; Witt, Mao\u00a0&amp; Keeton <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Treu\u00a0&amp; Marshall <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Bonvin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) and microlensing studies (e.g. Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A quadruplet configuration requires an even closer alignment of source and deflector than doubles. The fraction of quadruplets in statistically complete quasar lens samples is estimated at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$14{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a>). The two quadruplets found within this search, WG210014.9-445206.4 and WG021416.37-210535.3, correspond to <em>Gaia</em>-DR2 triplets and are already shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. Most of the other candidates, except some radio-selected and spectroscopically selected candidates, are doubles. We emphasize that, while WG\u00a00214-2105 requires little follow-up for confirmation, in principle the chromaticity in WG\u00a02100-4452 requires a final step of spectroscopic confirmation to secure its lensing nature.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn9\" data-open=\"fn9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">9</a></sup> Still, both have been shown to be easily compatible with simple lens models (Wynne\u00a0&amp; Schechter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Two other quadruplets found in this search, at J0405\u22123308 and J0053\u22122012, have also been discovered independently within the STRIDES<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn10\" data-open=\"fn10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">10</a></sup> collaboration (Schechter\u00a0&amp; Treu, private communication). Even though they were found <em>blindly</em> by our search, using exclusively public data sets, and so would be legitimate candidates in the framework of this paper, we prefer to list them as known lenses (Anguita et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_62_1567401739549\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_62_1567401739549\" data-open=\"bib1_62_1567401739549\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; STRIDES in preparation).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=157796268 id=\"157796268\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-4>3.4 Completeness and purity</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The statistics of quadruplets is also an indication of completeness in a quasar lens search, relative to the number of objects at pre-selection. One could also use two-image lenses for the same computation, but those generally require extensive campaigns of spectroscopic confirmation, whereas quadruplets are almost unmistakeable already from photometry and simple modelling (as e.g. by Wynne\u00a0&amp; Schechter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). What follows is a simple check based on <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a> as reanalysed by Treu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) and more agnostic estimates (i.e. independent of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a>) from known lenses in the smaller footprint of KiDS (\u2248450\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup>) by Spiniello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A \u2018demanding\u2019 quasar pre-selection (e.g. <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$W1-W2\\gt 0.55+\\sqrt{(\\delta W1)^{2}+(\\delta W2)^{2}}$|\u2060</span>; Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>) produces \u224840 objects per square degree, which (adopting <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a> lensing rates) gives \u224820 lenses over the DES footprint, of which \u22482.8\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.67 should be quads. A <em>WISE</em> pre-selection like the ones in this paper produces 110\u00a0\u00b1\u00a010 objects per square degree, and should result in 7.7\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.7 quadruplets over the DES footprint.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The numbers given above, however, adopt a rough <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a> estimate that may simply be unreliable. In fact, the lensing rate of quasars is not a direct measurement of those that can actually be detected or recognized, due e.g. to the image quality of a survey or the relative importance of fluxes from quasar images and deflector galaxies. Treu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) have compared a mock sample of lensed quasars, built along the lines of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a> and rendered into the imaging specifics of the DES, and found that the estimated rates agree with the currently known lenses (including some reported in this paper) only at the bright end (<em>i</em> \u2272 18.1), and many lenses predicted by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a>+DES were probably undiscovered at fainter magnitudes. On the other hand, Spiniello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) have found that there are at least 9 quasar lenses in the KiDS-450 footprint, whereas the same <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a> estimates would have predicted 6. Therefore, the expected number of lenses (including quadruplets) should be \u22481.5\u00a0times higher, predicting \u224812 quadruplets in the DES footprint from our pre-selection criteria.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For the searches in this paper, the lensing rates should also be multiplied by the \u22480.6 success rate by which the NCSA cut-out server correctly displayed images,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn11\" data-open=\"fn11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">11</a></sup> yielding again \u22487 quadruplets over the DES from our choices of pre-selection \u2013 or 5\u201310, adopting simplistic Poissonian statistics and fluctuations in the NCSA cut-out display success rate. Then, the 9 quadruplets (discovered or recovered) in this paper suggest that the steps of target and candidate selection are reasonably complete.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to find more quads, then, the main bottleneck is that of colour pre-selection. Searches with hybrid, optical\u2013IR colours would allow one to relax the <em>WISE</em> extragalactic cuts, but in this exploration, we preferred to use the DES-DR1 only for the final stage of visual inspection in order not to impose a prejudice on the optical colours of lensed quasars upon our searches.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The number of quadruplets also indicated the expected purity of the whole candidate sample. With the figures above, we would expect \u224860 candidate doubles to actually be lenses. The current sample of \u2248100 candidates then suggests a purity of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\approx}60{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>. The success rate of ongoing spectroscopic campaigns (Spiniello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) confirms this estimate.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=157796275 id=\"157796275\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have discovered two previously unknown quadruplets, WG210014.9-445206.4 and WG021416.37-210535.3. We have independently discovered another two (J0053\u22122012, J0405\u22123308) found independently within STRIDES (Anguita et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_62_1567401739549\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_62_1567401739549\" data-open=\"bib1_62_1567401739549\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; STRIDES in preparation), which we prefer to list among other known lenses in the DES footprint.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The use of five different selection methods, over spectral ranges ranging from X-ray to radio through optical, has resulted in 100 quasar lens candidates over the DES-DR1 public footprint. The number of quadruplets found in this paper suggests that the searches are reasonably complete and that the main bottleneck is the very first step of object pre-selection</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">All of the searches involved a step of <em>WISE</em> pre-selection, imposing some loose cuts on colours in order to isolate extragalactic objects, and results in two main clusters of candidates based on whether their photometry is quasar dominated or galaxy dominated. Due to the capabilities of the DESaccess server with large cut-out queries, at least at the time when these searches were performed, approximately two-thirds of targets in the DES-DR1 footprint were properly displayed, so another \u224850 candidates may be still awaiting discovery.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The depth of lens searches is still an open issue. Despite the nominal depth (<em>i</em> \u2248 22.5) of the DES public data, current campaigns over the DES footprint are covering the brighter end (<em>i</em> \u2272 18.5, as shown by Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Spiniello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). This is partly due to the completeness limit of <em>Gaia</em>, and the need to identify promising candidates upon visual inspection. From the searches in this paper, a pre-selection-based e.g. radio or X-ray emission seems to aid the identification of lens candidates at fainter (optical and IR) magnitudes than has been possible so far (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=157796280 id=\"157796280\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 Deeper and sharper <em>WISE</em> pre-selection</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">At the stage of <em>WISE</em> pre-selection, we are currently limited by two factors: the uncertainties in <em>W</em>1, <em>W</em>2, <em>W</em>3 magnitudes; and image resolution. First, the searches are cut at <em>W</em>1\u00a0&lt;\u00a017 and <em>W</em>2\u00a0&lt;\u00a015.6, since the magnitudes of fainter objects are more affected by Earth-shine and become quickly unreliable. Secondly, the \u22486\u00a0arcsec (full width at half-maximum, FWHM) image resolution of <em>WISE</em> prevents any comparison of the mid-IR colours of different components, which at these wavelengths should be unaffected by reddening and microlensing and would then make a powerful selection criterion.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Forced photometry upon <em>WISE</em> cut-outs, using object positions from sharper surveys (like Gaia or the DES), would alleviate these issues and enable a deeper and sharper search, maximizing the information content of <em>WISE</em>. This, of course, requires that multiple components are identified by the optical surveys and that their separation is wide enough (\u22732.5\u00a0arcsec) so that the magnitudes inferred through forced photometry are reliable. From a re-reduction (Meisner, Lang\u00a0&amp; Schlegel <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) and forward modelling of <em>WISE</em>/Neo<em>WISE</em> survey tiles, forced-photometry magnitudes are currently available for the SDSS (Lang, Hogg\u00a0&amp; Schlegel <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) and the DECaLS (Dey et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) footprints, covering \u2018Northern\u2019 declinations above \u221220\u00a0deg. By using <em>Gaia</em> multiplets as a base for forced photometry, a search based on mid-IR (deblended) colours may be extended to the whole sky. However, the completeness of the resulting sample would be ill characterized, as the current releases of <em>Gaia</em> fail to properly deblend lenses (e.g. WGD\u00a00150, WGD\u00a00245, Agnello <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) that are clearly deblended into multiplets by other surveys such as the DES.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Another way of increasing depth and imaging resolution, in the BaROQuES approach, would be to replace 2MASS with deeper surveys, such as UKIDSS (Warren et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) or VHS (McMahon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). However, their sky coverage is not homogeneous, whereas 2MASS covers the whole sky, and their application to a DES search is of limited use since their overlap with the DES footprint is only partial. Wile UKIDDS is primarily a Northern hemisphere survey, VHS was planned to cover the whole Southern hemisphere, but<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn12\" data-open=\"fn12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">12</a></sup> it is mostly limited to \u221220 \u2264 Dec. &lt; 0 and \u221250 \u2264 Dec. &lt; \u221240, and not homogeneously.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=157796284 id=\"157796284\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>4.2 Towards the LSST</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">While near-IR surveys (e.g. VHS, UKIDSS, and VHS) are ideally suited for chromatic offsets, due to the different colours of sources and deflectors, optical surveys can be a valid alternative. Lemon et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2_121_1567403907218\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2_121_1567403907218\" data-open=\"bib2_121_1567403907218\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) have successfully used SDSS instead of 2MASS, and our BaROQuES procedures have been applied with success to the KiDS-DR3 450\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> footprint (Spiniello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). In the near future, LSST (SV due 2022, SciOps due 2023) will enable the extension of these searches to the whole Southern hemisphere.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Despite the deluge of multi-epoch data from the full survey, the foreseen volume of nightly observations is still manageable, and automated procedures for chromatic offsets can be run on a nightly basis. This pipeline-oriented approach will then bring the discovery of lensed quasars to the same, high-cadence pace of transient discoveries. Ideally, chromatic offsets can be computed among different bands within LSST, without the recourse to external surveys like <em>Gaia</em> or 2MASS, provided nightly data are deep enough to guarantee robust astrometry in separate bands.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=157796287 id=\"157796287\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3>4.3 <em>Gaia</em> DR3, DR4, and <em>Euclid</em></h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The DR2 of <em>Gaia</em> provided additional information over DR1, such as blue and red pass-band magnitudes (<em>G</em><sub>bp</sub>, <em>G</em><sub>rp</sub>), as well as parallax and proper motion, for sources towards the bright end. It has a safety cut-off at \u22480.5\u00a0arcsec nearest neighbours, which prevents the discovery of small-separation lenses through multiplet recognition but may be reassessed in future releases. The pipeline proper motions of known lenses are not necessarily small (Spiniello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), and colours from <em>G</em><sub>bp</sub>, <em>G</em><sub>rp</sub> can only be used for the brighter candidates.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The final <em>Gaia</em>-DR4 release, due in 2020, is planned to provide low-resolution spectra of all detected <em>Gaia</em> sources. This would provide a selection of lens candidates based uniquely on <em>Gaia</em>, bypassing broad-band colour selection, through the detection of emission lines from the source quasars. This approach closely resembles the Hamburg-ESO strategy of isolating quasars based on their low-resolution spectra and following them up with higher imaging resolution, but it would be applied over the whole sky and down to fainter magnitudes.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Beyond the spectroscopic and multiplet selection in <em>Gaia</em>, an obvious step forward will be the Euclid space mission (Laureijs et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). The lessons learnt from the <em>Gaia</em> pipelines, in deblending objects into multiple sources and extracting spectra, will be essential to the development of lens searches within Euclid. In these all-sky perspectives, significant improvement is needed on the final stage of candidate selection, whether it is based on direct cutout modeling or direct visual inspection. Dedicated deblenders are being developed to this purpose (e.g. Chan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), but they still require manual \u2018tuning\u2019 to the specifics of each survey, and a considerable amount of visual inspection.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=157796291 id=\"157796291\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-4>4.4 Beyond <em>ROSAT</em>: <em>eROSITA</em></h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The optical and X-ray choices of pre-selection are quite complementary. On the one side, X-ray-selected sources populate the faint end of the <em>WISE</em> and <em>Gaia</em> magnitude distribution, and sometimes miss <em>Gaia</em><span class=\"monospace\">source</span> counterparts. On the other, only two of the known lenses in the DES are detected by our <em>ROSAT</em>\u2013<em>WISE</em> search, and in general X-ray-selected lenses are a minority among the CASTLES sample.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the near future, <em>eROSITA</em> (Merloni et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) promises a \u224820 deeper coverage than <em>ROSAT</em> in the soft X-ray, and the first ever all-sky survey in the hard X-ray. The forecast of \u2248100 detected objects per square degree, over the 4-yr span of the survey mission, is comparable to the <em>WISE</em> extragalactic selections used in this paper, and based on completely independent spectral signatures. In particular, from the expected number of active galactic nuclei (AGNs) with redshift 1 &lt; <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> &lt; 3 and the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a> estimates, <em>eROSITA</em> should detect \u2248120 lensed quasars over its 30\u00a0000\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> footprint, a quarter of which would have an obscured AGN as a source.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=157796294 id=\"157796294\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" data-legacy-id=ack1>ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We thank the anonymous referee for a remark on Completeness and Purity that spawned the discussion in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4</a>, and T.\u00a0Treu and P.\u00a0L.\u00a0Schechter for discussions of issues with translating <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a> forecasts from detectability to discoverability. CS wishes to thank N.\u00a0R.\u00a0Napolitano for interesting discussions about lens searches. AA wishes to thank P.\u00a0L.\u00a0Schechter for support and encouragement, and gratefully acknowledges hospitality by the Harvard ITC in 2018 February\u2013April, where the <em>Gaia</em>-DR2 searches were run.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">CS has received funding from the European Union\u2019s Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme under the Marie Sklodowska-Curie actions grant agreement no. 664931. AA is supported by a grant from VILLUM FONDEN (project number 16599). This project is funded by the Danish council for independent research under the project \u2018Fundamentals of Dark Matter Structures\u2019, DFF -6108-00470.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This research made use of the cross-match service provided by CDS, Strasbourg. This research has made use of the NASA/IPAC Infrared Science Archive, which is operated by the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, under contract with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. This publication makes also use of data products from the 2MASS, which is a joint project of the University of Massachusetts and the Infrared Processing and Analysis Center/California Institute of Technology, funded by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the National Science Foundation.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This project used public archival data from the DES. Funding for the DES Projects has been provided by the U.S. Department of Energy, the U.S. National Science Foundation, the Ministry of Science and Education of Spain, the Science and Technology Facilities Council of the United Kingdom, the Higher Education Funding Council for England, the National Center for Supercomputing Applications at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, the Cientifico e Tecnologico and the Ministerio da Ciencia, Tecnologia e Inovacao, the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft, and the Collaborating Institutions in the DES.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" Tololo Inter-American Observatory, National Optical Astronomy Observatory, which is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy (AURA) under a cooperative agreement with the National Science Foundation.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=157796299 id=\"157796299\" class=\"backfootnotegroup-title\" >Footnotes</h2>\r\n<div content-id=\"fn1\"><span Institutions.</p></div></span></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=157796313 id=\"157796313\" class=\"backreferences-title\" data-legacy-id=ref1>REFERENCES</h2>\r\n<div class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\"><span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Abbott</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">T.             </span>\r\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n<div class=\"pub-history-wrap clearfix\">\r\n\r\n        <div class=\"pub-history-row clearfix\">\r\n            <div href='https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/stz2200'>https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/stz2200</a></div>\r\n        </div>\r\n        <div class=\"pub-history-row clearfix\">\r\n            <div class=\"ww-citation-date-wrap\">\r\n                <div class=\"citation-label\">Published:</div>\r\n                <div class=\"citation-date\">12 August 2019</div>\r\n            </div>\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"ww-citation-history-wrap js-article-history st-article-history\">\r\n                    <span>Article history</span><i class=\"icon-general-arrow-filled-down        <div class=\"wi-state\">Received:</div>\r\n                    <div class=\"wi-date\">28 May 2018</div>\r\n                </div>\r\n                <div class=\"history-entry\">\r\n                    <div class=\"wi-state\">Revision received:</div>\r\n                    <div class=\"wi-date\">23 July 2019</div>\r\n                </div>\r\n                <div class=\"history-entry\">\r\n                    <div class=\"wi-state\">Accepted:</div>\r\n                    <div class=\"wi-date\">06 August 2019</div>\r\n                </div>\r\n                <div js-content-body\">\r\n            <div class=\"toolbar-wrap js-toolbar-wrap\">\r\n                <div class=\"toolbar-inner-wrap\">\r\n                    <ul id=\"Toolbar\" role=\"navigation\">\r\n    <li class=\"toolbar-item item-pdf\">\r\n        <a class=\"al-link pdf article-pdfLink\" data-article-id=\"5548822\" href=\"/mnras/article-pdf/489/2/2525/29809292/stz2200.pdf\">\r\n            <img src=//oup.silverchair-cdn.com/UI/app/svg/pdf.svg alt=\"pdf\" /><span class=\"pdf-link-text\">PDF</span>\r\n        </a>\r\n    </li>\r\n                                                    <li class=\"toolbar-item item-link item-split-view\">\r\n                                <a href=\"javascript:;\"\r\n                                   class=\"split-view js-split-view st-split-view\"\r\n                                   target=\"\">\r\n                                    <i class=\"icon-menu_split\"></i>\r\n                                    Split View\r\n                                </a>\r\n                            </li>\r\n                        <li class=\"toolbar-item item-with-dropdown item-views\">\r\n                            <a class=\"at-views-dropdown drop-trigger\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-dropdown=\"FilterDrop\" aria-haspopup=\"true\">\r\n                                <i class=\"icon-menu_views\"></i>\r\n                                <div class=\"toolbar-label\">\r\n                                    <div class=\"toolbar-text\">Views</div>\r\n                                    <i class=\"icon-general-arrow-filled-down               <li class=\"at-figures-tables article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"figures-tables\">\r\n                                    <a class=\"toolbar-item\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ToolboxGetCitation widget-instance-OUP_Get_Citation\">\n        <a href=\"#\" class=\"js-cite-button\" data-reveal-id=\"getCitation\" Society</em>, Volume 489, Issue 2, October 2019, Pages 2525\u20132535, <a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/stz2200\">https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/stz2200</a></p>\r\n        </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter\" id=\"navbar-search-filter\">\r\n       </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input     <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=157796214 id=\"157796214\" class=\"abstract-title\" >ABSTRACT</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We have scanned 5000\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> of Southern Sky to search for strongly lensed quasars with five methods, all source oriented, but based on different assumptions and selection criteria. We present a list of high-grade candidates from each method (totalling 98 unique, new candidates), to facilitate follow-up spectroscopic campaigns, including two previously unknown quadruplets, WG\u00a0210014.9-445206.4 and WG\u00a0021416.37-210535.3. We analyse morphological searches based on <em>Gaia</em> multiplet detection and astrometric offsets, fibre-spectroscopic pre-selection, and X-ray and radio pre-selection. The performance and complementarity of the methods are evaluated on a common sample of known lenses in the Dark Energy Survey public Data Release 1 (DR1) footprint. We recovered in total 13 known lenses, of which 8 are quadruplets. Morphological and colour selection of objects, from the <em>WISE</em> and<em>Gaia</em>-DR2 surveys, recovers most of those known lenses, but searches in the radio and X-ray cover regimes that are beyond the completeness of <em>Gaia</em>. Given the footprint, pre-selection, and depth limits, the current number of quads indicates that the union of these searches is complete, and the expected purity on high-grade candidates is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\approx}60{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>. Ongoing, spectroscopic campaigns confirm this estimate.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"catalogues\">catalogues</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: formation&quot;\">galaxies: formation</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;dark matter&quot;\">dark matter</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=157796216 id=\"157796216\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Sizeable samples of gravitationally lensed quasars, spanning a range in redshift, image separation, and mass, are essential to various scientific purposes. However, these objects are extremely rare: according to Oguri\u00a0&amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a>), one in \u224810<sup>4</sup> quasars is strongly lensed. One of the first efforts to build a large and well-studied statistical sample of strong gravitational-lensed quasars has been made by The Cosmic Lens All-Sky Survey (CLASS; Myers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>). CLASS has obtained high-resolution radio images from the Very Large Array (VLA; at 8.4\u00a0GHz) of over 13\u00a0000 flat-spectrum radio sources, finding 22 radio-loud lenses. However, in radio lens surveys like CLASS, the redshift distribution of the flat-spectrum sources is poorly constrained (e.g. Mu\u00f1oz et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>). Only with the advent of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS; York et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>), which in its 14th Data Release confirmed 526\u00a0356 quasars spectroscopically (P\u00e2ris et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), has it been possible to construct a large sample of lensed quasars also in the optical (e.g. The Sloan Digital Sky Survey Quasar Lens Search, SQLS; Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), beyond the bright lenses identified in older searches.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">More recently, thanks to new imaging sky surveys, with wide footprints and sufficient depth and image quality, like ATLAS (Shanks et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), DES (The Dark Energy Survey Collaboration <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; The Dark Energy Survey Collaboration et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), and KiDS (de Jong et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), the search for lensed quasars has received new impetus. Nevertheless, to this day, a big portion of the Southern Sky still remains unexplored and the spatial density on sky of known lenses remains much higher at Dec. &gt; 0.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to fully exploit the wealth of data from different surveys, a suite of new methods to search for lensed quasars (QSOs) have been developed, based on morphology and visual inspection (Diehl et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Lin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>); spectroscopy (e.g. Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>); data mining on catalogue magnitudes (Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015a</a>; Agnello <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Williams, Agnello\u00a0&amp; Treu <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>); and variability (Berghea et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As recently quantified by Spiniello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), different search methods are somewhat complementary, as each search relies on different criteria and ancillary information. The application of multiple, state-of-the-art methods over the same footprint then serves two scopes: assessing the role of selection bias in lens samples; and maximizing purity and completeness in lens searches.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">With this paper, we perform a comparison study over the footprint covered by the Dark Energy Survey (DES) DR1 (The Dark Energy Survey Collaboration et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), and present new lens candidates. Our choice is motivated by three criteria: the DES-DR1 release is public, which ensures reproducibility; its footprint lies mostly in the South, which is still largely unexplored; and the sheer convenience of display from the NCSA DESaccess cut-out service,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup> which enabled a swift visual inspection of image cut-outs. Magnitudes <em>W</em>1, <em>W</em>2, <em>W</em>3 from the <em>Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer</em> (hereafter <em>WISE</em>; Wright et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) and from the <em>Gaia</em> space mission (Gaia Collaboration et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) are given in their native Vega system.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The paper is organized as follows. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, we describe each of the search methods, and its possible biases. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>, we estimate the performance of each method, in terms of known lens recovery and of new candidates produced over the DES-DR1 footprint. We also provide tables of candidates, to facilitate spectroscopic follow-up, including at least two \u2018new\u2019 quadruplets: WG\u00a0210014.9-445206.4 and WG\u00a0021416.37-210535.3 (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). We conclude in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"157796223\" scrollto-destination=\"157796223\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/489/2/10.1093_mnras_stz2200/2/m_stz2200fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611464883&amp;Signature=LAAPiEizxraPd24mz92PBXQzk44NMpBJEsk4ldj-ZDOsTvCnlbmvdBuHKapkgzRsqupJ4l33fG8QUUYqXOJAY6OZ~G1OqZHFhrk26~WaLtDoewYlTlYo29CdEwdB82w1bHStKqSogUtegBUlRfWeTZhONvzukb6~3a8vTXPtbiUx1iOiwm8WlbDC5wd-Obwzmn4k9nbWpjL2O57bou0FUUe4h-ymKjcf~O5r71Zcv3ebn-~qb~54aIg4ZX1kc5Sxa-mSNYeBJYyQ9DoJFqvdVAfRHatA9sqQAF5NBKmvXEEO-ju199nlkPO-L~BgABSoWLa~~kcdFWCgYZkDD~ruow__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The nine quadruplets found by at least one method in the DES public footprint, with WISE extragalactic colours. Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> gives references for all quadruplets.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/489/2/10.1093_mnras_stz2200/2/m_stz2200fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611464883&amp;Signature=LAAPiEizxraPd24mz92PBXQzk44NMpBJEsk4ldj-ZDOsTvCnlbmvdBuHKapkgzRsqupJ4l33fG8QUUYqXOJAY6OZ~G1OqZHFhrk26~WaLtDoewYlTlYo29CdEwdB82w1bHStKqSogUtegBUlRfWeTZhONvzukb6~3a8vTXPtbiUx1iOiwm8WlbDC5wd-Obwzmn4k9nbWpjL2O57bou0FUUe4h-ymKjcf~O5r71Zcv3ebn-~qb~54aIg4ZX1kc5Sxa-mSNYeBJYyQ9DoJFqvdVAfRHatA9sqQAF5NBKmvXEEO-ju199nlkPO-L~BgABSoWLa~~kcdFWCgYZkDD~ruow__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The nine quadruplets found by at least one method in the DES public footprint, with WISE extragalactic colours. The 11.5\u00a0arcsec\u00a0\u00d7 11.5\u00a0arcsec cut-outs are obtained from the DES Data Access page, and are shown in DES <em>gri</em> bands. WG\u00a02100-4452 is a previously unknown quad, and the discovery of WG\u00a00214-2105 has been recently reported by Agnello (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>, RNAAS). WG\u00a0J0053-2012 and WG\u00a00405-33 have been found independently in STRIDES (Anguita et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_62_1567401739549\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_62_1567401739549\" data-open=\"bib1_62_1567401739549\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Schechter\u00a0&amp; Treu, private communication). Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> gives references for all quadruplets.</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=157796224 id=\"157796224\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 THE METHODS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We use five different methods, of which two are mostly morphological and rely on <em>Gaia</em> multiplet detection or chromatic offsets; one is based on spectroscopic pre-selection from fibre-spectroscopic surveys; and two are based on radio and X-ray pre-selection</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The searches are structured similarly: a first step of <em>object pre-selection</em>, based on shallow cuts on catalogue magnitudes and colours; a second step of <em>target</em> selection, still based on catalogue entries; and a final step of <em>candidate</em> selection, through visual inspection of image cut-outs. For the sake of convenience, the DES-DR1 public cut-out service was used. However, in its current version, it properly displays between 50\u00a0per\u2009cent and 70\u00a0per\u2009cent of the cut-outs that are produced due to software issues.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a></sup> For this reason, the final numbers of candidates given in this paper should be taken as purely indicative, and a significant number of quasar lenses may still be found among the systems that were not properly displayed.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In what follows, the general performance on known systems is evaluated using a <em>benchmark</em> list of 214 known quasar lenses and pairs, collated from the CASTLES and SQLS (Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) data bases, consistently with previous work (Williams et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). When restricting to the DES footprint, we will also consider lenses that have been found more recently through different endeavours (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"157796228\" scrollto-destination=\"157796228\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Known lenses in the DES-DR1 public footprint recovered by the different search methods of Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>. Magnitudes are from <em>WISE</em> and <em>Gaia</em>-DR1 and given in the Vega system. The first six systems in the table are the known quadruplets, whose cut-outs are also shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. Here, W2MG1 denotes 2MASS-versus-<em>Gaia</em> chromatic offsets (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.1</a>), and \u2018mult\u2019 or \u2018sing\u2019 marks objects that correspond to <em>Gaia</em> multiplets or singlets, respectively.</p></div> </div><div (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3_212_1567692831961\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3_212_1567692831961\" data-open=\"bib3_212_1567692831961\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J202139.38\u2212411557.9\u00a0</td><td>14.17\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>13.17\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>10.44\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.07\u00a0</td><td>19.27\u00a0</td><td>W2MG1mult, GaiaDR2mult\u00a0</td><td>Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>)\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>object<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>W</em>1<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>W</em>2<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>W</em>3<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>G</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Methods<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Reference<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>J005344.44\u2212201233.7\u00a0</td><td>14.56\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>14.01\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04\u00a0</td><td>10.76\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.10\u00a0</td><td>19.21\u00a0</td><td>GaiaDR2mult\u00a0</td><td>STRIDES (in preparation)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J021416.37\u2212210535.3\u00a0</td><td>15.11\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>14.68\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.06\u00a0</td><td>11.82\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.24\u00a0</td><td>19.80\u00a0</td><td>GaiaDR2mult\u00a0</td><td>Agnello (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>, RNAAS)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J023233.16\u2212211725.7\u00a0</td><td>14.02\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>12.99\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>10.06\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.05\u00a0</td><td>18.93\u00a0</td><td>XMMslew\u00a0</td><td>Wisotzki et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J025942.86\u2212163543.0\u00a0</td><td>13.86\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>13.13\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>10.03\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.05\u00a0</td><td>19.22\u00a0</td><td>W2MG1sing\u00a0</td><td>Schechter et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J040559.76\u2212330851.0\u00a0</td><td>13.85\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>12.71\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02\u00a0</td><td>9.94\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04\u00a0</td><td>20.22\u00a0</td><td>W2MG1mult, GaiaDR2mult\u00a0</td><td>Anguita et\u00a0al.
