(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J023527.42\u2212243313.8\u00a0</td><td>14.00\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>13.02\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>10.29\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.05\u00a0</td><td>18.12\u00a0</td><td>W2MG1mult, GaiaDR2mult\u00a0</td><td>Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J051410.90\u2212332622.4\u00a0</td><td>13.29\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>11.71\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02\u00a0</td><td>8.54\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02\u00a0</td><td>17.80\u00a0</td><td>HE, RASS\u00a0</td><td>Gregg et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3_212_1567692831961\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3_212_1567692831961\" data-open=\"bib3_212_1567692831961\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J202139.38\u2212411557.9\u00a0</td><td>14.17\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>13.17\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>10.44\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.07\u00a0</td><td>19.27\u00a0</td><td>W2MG1mult, GaiaDR2mult\u00a0</td><td>Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>)\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/157796228\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=157796229 id=\"157796229\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 BaROQuES: blue and red offsets of quasars and extragalactic sources</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Here, we exploit observations of the same objects across different surveys, under the hypothesis that lenses can show astrometric offsets (across surveys with different waveband coverage, or depth, or image quality) due to the presence of different components. This enables a catalogue-based selection of composite objects regardless of blending issues, before examining the image cutouts.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The <em>Gaia</em> mission had \u22482\u00a0arcsec image resolution in DR1 and \u22480.5\u00a0arcsec in DR2, which enables the recognition of multiple images in lensed quasars that are otherwise not deblended by the image-processing pipelines of ground-based surveys. The search of quasar lenses in DES through <em>Gaia</em>-DR1 multiplet recognition has already been made within STRIDES (Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>). However, not all known lenses are deblended into multiple <span class=\"monospace\">source</span> entries in <em>Gaia</em>-DR1 (e.g. Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>). For this reason, we need complementary techniques to cope with incomplete deblending, in order to maximize completeness on lens searches.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For systems that are not <em>Gaia</em> multiplets, we can still use the accurate astrometry of <em>Gaia</em> to compare shifts in image centroids among different surveys. To this aim, we consider objects that are bright enough to have positions in the 2-Micron All-Sky Survey (2MASS) catalogue, and consider their 2MASS-<em>Gaia</em> offsets. Matters are slightly complicated, due to atmospheric differential refraction (ADR) and the choice of astrometric calibrators for each survey. Recent searches based on chromatic offsets (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) relied on SDSS-versus-<em>Gaia</em> solutions, calibrated on astrometric reference stars, and had abundant contamination from isolated (unlensed) quasars. This is due to the different colours of quasars and astrometric stars, which can result in \u22480.3\u00a0arcsec offsets due to ADR (with typical \u224820\u00a0deg zenith angles of ground-based surveys).</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We resolve this by means of field-corrected offsets, using our own BaROQuES scripts,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">3</a></sup> as follows. First, we work with a sample of quasar-like objects, selected in <em>WISE</em> as<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">4</a></sup><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nW1-W2\\gt 0.35-\\sqrt{(\\delta W1)^{2}+(\\delta W2)^{2}},\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}\r\n$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ2\" content-id=\"equ2\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nW1-W2\\gt 0.2+\\sqrt{(\\delta W1)^{2}+(\\delta W2)^{2}},\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}\r\n$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(2)</span></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ3\" content-id=\"equ3\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nW2-W3\\gt 2.1+\\sqrt{(\\delta W2)^{2}+(\\delta W3)^{2}},\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}\r\n$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(3)</span></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ4\" content-id=\"equ4\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nW1\\lt 17, W2\\lt 15.6, W3\\lt 11.8.\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}\r\n$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(4)</span></div>Then, for each given object we examine a surrounding patch of 1.0\u00a0\u00d7\u00a01.0\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup>, containing \u224840 QSO-like neighbours. We then compute the average offsets between their 2MASS and <em>Gaia</em> coordinates \u03b4<em>x</em>\u00a0= \u2212cos\u2009(Dec.)\u03b4RA, \u03b4<em>y</em>\u00a0= \u03b4Dec., subtract them from the offsets of the given object, and retain it only if this corrected offset is between 0.27 and 1.8\u00a0arcsec. This ensures that known lenses are recovered, and chance alignments of quasars with other objects are safely rejected. The lower threshold in separation is chosen because the root-mean-square (field-corrected) offsets of isolated objects can be up to 0.2\u20130.3\u00a0arcsec in each patch.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">When applied to the Southern Galactic hemisphere, with <em>b</em> &lt; \u221220 and \u221270 &lt; Dec. &lt; 7, this gave \u22486\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>4</sup> objects, of which 31\u00a0381 singlets and 770 multiplets in the DES-DR1 footprint.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=157796235 id=\"157796235\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 <em>Gaia</em>-DR2 multiplets</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The nominal resolution of <em>Gaia</em> has improved from 2\u00a0arcsec (DR1) to 0.4\u00a0arcsec (DR2), so a simple upgrade consists in searching again for <em>Gaia</em>-DR2 multiplets corresponding to <em>WISE</em> sources. There is indeed some improvement from DR1 to DR2: out of the \u22486\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>4</sup><em>Gaia</em>-DR1 singlet \u2018BaROQuES\u2019 from above, a match with DR2 gave 2149 multiplets, of which 134 with more than two <span class=\"monospace\">source</span> entries.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">However, some candidates and small-separation lenses from DR1 have disappeared in the passage to DR2 (e.g. WGD0508; Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>). The same has been noticed by Spiniello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) on a smaller footprint (KiDS-DR3, 450\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup>). In general, the <em>Gaia</em>-specific deblending does not seem to have a well-defined behaviour with separation and flux ratios, as some small-separation lenses are recognized as multiplets while larger-separation lenses correspond to <em>Gaia</em> singlets (e.g. WGD0150, WGD0245; Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>).</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">In order to make additional progress over the searches in <em>Gaia</em>-DR1, we also relaxed the pre-selection photometric criteria. From a <em>WISE</em> search, we selected extragalactic objects as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"update217119_equ5\" content-id=\"update217119_equ5\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nW1-W2\\,\\gt\\, 0.2+\\sqrt{(\\delta W1)^{2}+(\\delta W2)^{2}},\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}\r\n$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(5)</span></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ6\" content-id=\"equ6\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nW1\\lt 17, W3\\lt 12.4\\\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}\r\n$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(6)</span></div>basically excluding stars (<em>W</em>1 \u2212 <em>W</em>2 \u2248 0) and fainter objects with unreliable catalogue magnitudes. This gave <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {O}(10^6)$|</span> objects with Galactic latitude <em>b</em> &lt; \u221215. Of these, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {O}(10^5)$|</span> are recognized as multiplets in <em>Gaia</em>-DR2.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn5\" data-open=\"fn5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">5</a></sup> However, many are clustered towards the Galactic disc and the Magellanic Clouds, which can be explained with the line-of-sight alignment of quasars with stars. In order to exclude most quasar-star pair contaminants, we then impose a threshold on the ratio \u03a3<sub>m</sub>/\u03a3<sub>s</sub>, between densities of multiplets (\u03a3<sub>m</sub>) and singlets (\u03a3<sub>s</sub>), estimated in 0.5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a00.5\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> patches around each multiplet.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn6\" data-open=\"fn6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">6</a></sup> For the <em>Gaia</em> doubles, we retain only objects in regions where \u03a3<sub>m</sub>/\u03a3<sub>s</sub> &lt; 0.2; for <em>Gaia</em> triplets and quadruplets, we relax it to \u03a3<sub>m</sub>/\u03a3<sub>s</sub> &lt; 0.3. After the overdensity threshold cuts, \u224817\u00a0000 multiplets remain, of which 8146 lie in the DES-DR1 public footprint.</div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=157796239 id=\"157796239\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-3>2.3 Spectroscopic surveys</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Some of the longest known quasar lenses, such as e.g. Q0957+561 (Walsh, Carswell\u00a0&amp; Weymann <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1979</a>) and lenses from the Hamburg-ESO survey (Wisotzki et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>), were found in wide-field, prism spectroscopic surveys. Over the last decade, searches in the SDSS and BOSS (Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) relied on samples of objects that were classified as quasar based on fibre spectroscopy. Also, some lenses recently found in the DES (Ostrovski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>) had pre-existing fibre spectra in the Anglo-Australian Observatory data bases, where they had been targeted as quasars or galaxies and not recognized as lenses, due to low image resolution.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For this reason, we examined two surveys with moderate depth and uniform coverage over large areas in the Southern hemisphere: the six-degree field galaxy survey (6dFGS; Jones et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) and the 2QZ (Boyle et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>). These two surveys were also based on different pre-selection cuts, based on optical cuts in all-sky surveys of moderate depth, focusing on galaxy-like (6dFGS) or quasar-like (2QZ) objects. In this sense, then, they are also complementary to the <em>WISE</em> criteria that we have used in our photometric searches.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We restrict these samples to objects with<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn7\" data-open=\"fn7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">7</a></sup><em>pipeline redshifts z</em><sub>s</sub> &gt; 0.5, as expected from simulated samples (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a>) and our benchmark of CASTLES/SQLS known lenses. This gave 1625 objects from the 6dFGS and 7147 from 2QZ, over the DES footprint. Due to the different choices in optical colour pre-selection of the 6dFGS and 2QZ, there is no overlap between the candidate samples from these two surveys.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=157796243 id=\"157796243\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-4>2.4 X-Ray</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Quasars can also be identified by X-ray emission, due to lower dust attenuation in that spectral range. The recently vetted cross-match (Salvato et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) the <em>ROSAT</em> all-sky survey (Boller et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) and XMMslew survey (Georgakakis\u00a0&amp; Nandra <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) with <em>WISE</em> then provides an alternative pre-selection of possible candidates. Some lenses discovered in <em>ROSAT</em> are indeed known, such as RXJ0911.4+0551 (Bade et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>), RXJ0921+4529 (Mu\u00f1oz et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>), and RXJ1131\u22121231 (Sluse et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>). A fainter lens, CY2201\u22123201 (Castander et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) was found in the <em>Chandra</em> deep fields.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We then used the publicly available cross-match tables<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn8\" data-open=\"fn8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">8</a></sup> to pre-select X-ray objects. Also in this search, we excluded possible stars with the same cuts as above (equations\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-update217119_equ5\"></span><a href=\"#update217119_equ5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ6\"></span><a href=\"#equ6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6</a>). This yielded 13\u00a0547 cut-outs from <em>ROSAT</em>\u2013<em>WISE</em> and 2294 from <em>XMM</em>\u2013<em>WISE</em>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=157796246 id=\"157796246\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-5>2.5 Radio</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Similarly to X-ray pre-selection, radio searches are less affected by reddening and by the presence of a foreground galaxy. As a consequence, they bypass the colour selection that can affect optical or IR searches. Indeed, quasar lens discoveries in the past have benefited from hemispheric surveys like the Parkes-MIT-NRAO survey (Griffith\u00a0&amp; Wright <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1993</a>) and dedicated observations by the CLASS (Myers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) and J-VLA (King et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>) searches.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Here, we use the Sydney University Molonglo Sky Survey (SUMSS; Mauch et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>), covering the Southern hemisphere down to \u224810\u00a0mJy at 0.84\u00a0GHz. We match the catalogue with <em>WISE</em>, using a nearest-neighbour match with 10\u00a0arcsec search radius, and retained extragalactic objects as above (equations\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-update217119_equ5\"></span><a href=\"#update217119_equ5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ6\"></span><a href=\"#equ6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6</a>). This resulted in 38\u00a0204 cut-outs within the DES-DR1 footprint.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=157796249 id=\"157796249\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 PERFORMANCE AND RESULTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The performance of each method can be quantified in different ways. One metric is given by completeness and purity with respect to previous searches. Another possibility is the number of candidates that are produced by each method over the same footprint. The final evaluation of performance is the purity of the candidate samples, once spectroscopic follow-up is performed. Most of the candidates presented in this paper are still awaiting spectroscopic confirmation, and published samples of lenses and contaminants over the DES footprint are still too small to build robust statistics. Then for the scope of this paper, we discuss the recovery of known lenses over DES-DR1, and properties of candidate samples from different searches. We also provide estimates of completeness and purity, based on the expected fraction of quadruplets. These are in line with findings of ongoing spectroscopic campaigns (Spiniello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=157796251 id=\"157796251\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 Known lenses and the DES subsample</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> lists the known lenses recovered over the DES-DR1 footprint. Five lenses are two image systems, and eight are (at least) quadruplets. Two of them (WG\u00a00405-3308 and WG\u00a00053-2012) have also been found, independently, within the STRIDES collaboration (Anguita et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_62_1567401739549\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_62_1567401739549\" data-open=\"bib1_62_1567401739549\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Schechter\u00a0&amp; Treu, private communication). The discovery of WG\u00a00214-2105 has been recently reported by Agnello (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). The two \u2018new\u2019 quad candidates, WG\u00a02100-4452 and WG\u00a00214-2105, have just recently been confirmed spectroscopically, and have been shown to be well reproducible by simple lens models (Wynne\u00a0&amp; Schechter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The recovery statistics of known lenses in <em>Gaia</em>-DR2 is slightly better than for <em>Gaia</em>-DR1 (e.g. Agnello <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). We quantify this through the <em>benchmark</em> list of 214 CASTLES/SQLS systems introduced in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>. Of these, 43 are missing from <em>Gaia</em>-DR2. Of the 171 that are detected, 124 are resolved in two sources, 15 into three sources, and 6 into four sources. Small-separation lenses are absent in <em>Gaia</em>-DR2, because of a sharper cut-off at \u22480.5\u00a0arcsec separations in the DR2 catalogue. These include also systems that were found thanks to <em>Gaia</em>-DR1 (e.g. WGD\u00a00508; Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=157796254 id=\"157796254\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 Candidates</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Visual inspection of targets from the above methods resulted in 16 BaROQuES in <em>Gaia</em>-DR1 versus 2MASS (not counting WG0214, already reported, see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>), of which 5 <em>Gaia</em> multiplets; 20 candidates from <em>Gaia</em>-DR2 multiplets (including WG2100, reported here for the first time); 7 candidates from fibre-spectroscopy (3 from 6dFGS and 4 from 2QZ); 29 candidates from X-ray pre-selection, of which 28 from <em>ROSAT</em>; and 26 candidates from SUMSS. The full lists of high-graded candidates are provided in Tables\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A2</a>, divided by search method. We list their names (J2000 coordinates), as well as their <em>WISE</em> (<em>W</em>1, <em>W</em>2, <em>W</em>3) and <em>Gaia</em>-DR1 (<em>G</em>) magnitudes. These total to 98 unique candidates.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The number of targets and candidates per square degree from each search depends on its depth and design. Searches relying on SUMSS, <em>ROSAT</em>, 2MASS, and <em>Gaia</em> resulted in comparable numbers of candidates (modulo the depth limits of each survey). The search based on the 6dFGS, while nominally using a hemispheric survey, resulted in much fewer candidates, because the catalogue objects themselves had been selected as nearby galaxy candidates based on their optical colours.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> shows the colour and magnitude distributions of the candidates. Different colours and markers represent the different methods through which the candidates have been identified. Known lenses are plotted in red (dashed in the magnitude histograms, triangles in the colour\u2013colour plot). <em>Gaia</em>-selected candidates extend the regime of known lenses towards fainter magnitudes, still with a cut-off at the faint end due to noisy <em>WISE</em> magnitudes and the drop in <em>Gaia</em> completeness at <em>G</em> \u2248 20. X-ray and radio-selected candidates populate the faint end of the magnitude distribution, with few objects corresponding to optical detections in <em>Gaia</em> (26 of these objects are missed by <em>Gaia</em> DR1 and/or DR2).</p>                        <a id=\"157796258\" scrollto-destination=\"157796258\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/489/2/10.1093_mnras_stz2200/2/m_stz2200fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611464883&amp;Signature=XCqL1UBvImyxfJKgQj9XGolPUSf4EVAILlu46Z91EK05lF7WFz8YTlSbus37679YyfBpAsm53r8sTYguwPMMRlK5ujHtOwrPiUbcRYzRRu7uxBoHq-jWfnH0xZ75R70gDWOrsXWHnHYWiWli85GyRsxJkY9HQrqj9b-uu3A5aZKYN4AISF9HIWcmGUCpoMZPZvpuyhixsZZaDW6wA2f3t3ZdEFbAJ9moZqeY~Y1udO2cZ8jECGcBZ3RY6B7r5qW7vxzRItFrZ03v8Tv6FtbiTrrbp002mYGyWXrMme-R1D26g5lmIpXQJl9IsidLUVi4T4LZsCgoCmUh1kQ94goZgg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Magnitude and colour distributions of candidates and known lenses. Middle: G \u2212magnitude distribution, with the same colour coding. Right: colours W1 \u2212 W2 versus W2 \u2212 W3, same colour coding (and markers) as in the first panel. We have added WG\u00a02100-4452 to the sample of \u2018known\u2019 quadruplets, instead of showing it separately. BaROQueS and Multiplets are grouped, because they are based on Gaia. Red triangles represent the known lenses recovered by the five searches.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/157796258/stz2200fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"157796258\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/489/2/10.1093_mnras_stz2200/2/stz2200fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611464883&Signature=vnQYwMHzcsZjHPeGsrk0Kq-BH0V2Z7RmFeitS9mUVm0~GaGfW2GwS7kHoGUOJy16nfuegFw9PeSqci5OplTJ2TaLpzLTYOGfB~7BB1qzTx5UzXXacv1kRzC7ECuD0VN91SvqOLrL-~MoLlnez3L-w~as7vYsig3~or~4Qhih9mkA6z1Ka2TjeCdtdznj1Quhln0PYkaI0~jmRtVGpz10AA5JODoNQyIdUZCVbAOviMrMBaMFr8uoHNGRuyEQukRxqxVN5-Nb1Iw5doQ1N~W30rM6cSucdNSZ5u1xGAfxnqz~EEjOobLPvGbeYv52NNkd0NisBfOxxbB9p8F8xLO8ng__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=157796258&ar=5548822&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Magnitude and colour distributions of candidates and known lenses. <em>Left: W</em>1 \u2212 magnitude distribution for <em>Gaia</em> candidates (blue), radio candidates (orange, dotted), X-ray candidates (green, dot\u2013dashed) and known lenses (red, dashed), truncated to the <em>WISE</em> completeness limit <em>W</em>1\u00a0=\u00a017. <em>Middle: G</em> \u2212magnitude distribution, with the same colour coding. <em>Right:</em> colours <em>W</em>1 \u2212 <em>W</em>2 versus <em>W</em>2 \u2212 <em>W</em>3, same colour coding (and markers) as in the first panel. We have added WG\u00a02100-4452 to the sample of \u2018known\u2019 quadruplets, instead of showing it separately. BaROQueS and Multiplets are grouped, because they are based on <em>Gaia</em>. Red triangles represent the known lenses recovered by the five searches.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/489/2/10.1093_mnras_stz2200/2/m_stz2200fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611464883&amp;Signature=XCqL1UBvImyxfJKgQj9XGolPUSf4EVAILlu46Z91EK05lF7WFz8YTlSbus37679YyfBpAsm53r8sTYguwPMMRlK5ujHtOwrPiUbcRYzRRu7uxBoHq-jWfnH0xZ75R70gDWOrsXWHnHYWiWli85GyRsxJkY9HQrqj9b-uu3A5aZKYN4AISF9HIWcmGUCpoMZPZvpuyhixsZZaDW6wA2f3t3ZdEFbAJ9moZqeY~Y1udO2cZ8jECGcBZ3RY6B7r5qW7vxzRItFrZ03v8Tv6FtbiTrrbp002mYGyWXrMme-R1D26g5lmIpXQJl9IsidLUVi4T4LZsCgoCmUh1kQ94goZgg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Magnitude and colour distributions of candidates and known lenses. Left: W1 \u2212 magnitude distribution for Gaia candidates (blue), radio candidates (orange, dotted), X-ray candidates (green, dot\u2013dashed) and known lenses (red, dashed), truncated to the WISE completeness limit W1\u00a0=\u00a017. Middle: G \u2212magnitude distribution, with the same colour coding. Right: colours W1 \u2212 W2 versus W2 \u2212 W3, same colour coding (and markers) as in the first panel. We have added WG\u00a02100-4452 to the sample of \u2018known\u2019 quadruplets, instead of showing it separately. BaROQueS and Multiplets are grouped, because they are based on Gaia. Red triangles represent the known lenses recovered by the five searches.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/157796258/stz2200fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"157796258\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/489/2/10.1093_mnras_stz2200/2/stz2200fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611464883&Signature=vnQYwMHzcsZjHPeGsrk0Kq-BH0V2Z7RmFeitS9mUVm0~GaGfW2GwS7kHoGUOJy16nfuegFw9PeSqci5OplTJ2TaLpzLTYOGfB~7BB1qzTx5UzXXacv1kRzC7ECuD0VN91SvqOLrL-~MoLlnez3L-w~as7vYsig3~or~4Qhih9mkA6z1Ka2TjeCdtdznj1Quhln0PYkaI0~jmRtVGpz10AA5JODoNQyIdUZCVbAOviMrMBaMFr8uoHNGRuyEQukRxqxVN5-Nb1Iw5doQ1N~W30rM6cSucdNSZ5u1xGAfxnqz~EEjOobLPvGbeYv52NNkd0NisBfOxxbB9p8F8xLO8ng__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=157796258&ar=5548822&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Magnitude and colour distributions of candidates and known lenses. <em>Left: W</em>1 \u2212 magnitude distribution for <em>Gaia</em> candidates (blue), radio candidates (orange, dotted), X-ray candidates (green, dot\u2013dashed) and known lenses (red, dashed), truncated to the <em>WISE</em> completeness limit <em>W</em>1\u00a0=\u00a017. <em>Middle: G</em> \u2212magnitude distribution, with the same colour coding. <em>Right:</em> colours <em>W</em>1 \u2212 <em>W</em>2 versus <em>W</em>2 \u2212 <em>W</em>3, same colour coding (and markers) as in the first panel. We have added WG\u00a02100-4452 to the sample of \u2018known\u2019 quadruplets, instead of showing it separately. BaROQueS and Multiplets are grouped, because they are based on <em>Gaia</em>. Red triangles represent the known lenses recovered by the five searches.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Two main clusters of systems are visible in the <em>WISE</em> colour\u2013colour plot: objects with high <em>W</em>1 \u2212 <em>W</em>2, compatible with QSO-dominated photometry, and systems with lower <em>W</em>1 \u2212 <em>W</em>2, compatible with galaxy-dominated photometry. Systems with low <em>W</em>1 \u2212 <em>W</em>2 (left-most panel) mostly have <em>W</em>3 \u226511.8, which is the threshold where <em>WISE</em> magnitudes become unreliable. There is a prevalence of radio-selected objects in the galaxy-dominated clump, whereas X-ray and <em>Gaia</em>-selected systems are evenly distributed. Known lenses are mostly associated with the QSO-dominated regime.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Candidates selected from each method are shown in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. All methods produce sensible results upon visual inspection, albeit with a pre-dominance of high-grade candidates from the<em>Gaia</em> searches. Some candidates (mostly from SUMMS and spectroscopic surveys) may be lenses with bright deflectors, or mergers of compact narrow-line galaxies at lower redshift. With the depth (<em>i</em> \u2248 22.5) and image resolution of Pan-STARRS and DES-DR1 (\u22480.26\u00a0arcsec\u00a0pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>, \u22481\u00a0arcsec seeing), these contaminants are still present in candidate samples.</p>                        <a id=\"157796261\" scrollto-destination=\"157796261\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/489/2/10.1093_mnras_stz2200/2/m_stz2200fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611464883&amp;Signature=Z7csyyZPt9KRhiiQSMqGTzUw1v8R4dfzQ03kmKvwUH-FVZXtEQEKLRD0WMMy7p-F5hPnWofSzyUj5r9fnjSV~Uo7JWX9xRYd2rwZZPFErJeZFG-B~ePGDLdstyGyqWaNDL4e-OBjCN1UO-AKESGo0THo7L0pzRESyTuhqVut-SdS06HNxNtjEy6uT2KEJ67B8Ud~cKN7ZtvIiBYlaf4J1gqwOFpSqf0AkYHZu3iI2Ti9JGLy8g8L91LYmfp-Lfz-CXb1hLZjakf-Dm9Jz6A~iGwC8Z8lluNRKNeSSNTvRO~gD1KNb-k1dc8Ql4srKSXlOEtisKmzD7kLCWm0T8bAXg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Examples of candidates found in Gaia DR1 and DR2, with WISE pre-selection (same colour scheme as in Fig.\u00a01). W2MG1 denotes WISE objects with acceptable offsets between their 2MASS and Gaia-DR1 catalogue positions, with recomputed astrometry from our BaROQuES scripts.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/157796261/stz2200fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"157796261\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/489/2/10.1093_mnras_stz2200/2/stz2200fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611464883&Signature=tbF3Bfgr1aoVI4w7jEs-OhSn~Y5OixY5F4IT8aih8TrDrz1dwQkL9-zLg0G5aFyUE14B-VaLgwR~zP~9CpcNMFLTHnzuWhmgqpATgKUqAs9e3~nA6LXZIXQgnroKeOsxWRHfHXPJIJYhdnRP1J98oYv0hkhQx5uoF4v3KL2xDonoxDbpnTItzmlRRC3diw5fqT8yQZYP3PW-8HFqoFCBdv6AzTuGsgBcj7l1i9Cge2KZ6asFkbCDaY5tOlKZnfyQ0Vy4FhP9QvLqS2Ft3Dy--WxH8c~RYJSikbEQxi6HF1QTGEIVRRQCft957kz1mTqXV5TlZj3JkFveYAmgJ8mvyw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=157796261&ar=5548822&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Examples of candidates found in <em>Gaia</em> DR1 and DR2, with <em>WISE</em> pre-selection (same colour scheme as in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). W2MG1 denotes <em>WISE</em> objects with acceptable offsets between their 2MASS and <em>Gaia</em>-DR1 catalogue positions, with recomputed astrometry from our BaROQuES scripts.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/489/2/10.1093_mnras_stz2200/2/m_stz2200fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611464883&amp;Signature=Z7csyyZPt9KRhiiQSMqGTzUw1v8R4dfzQ03kmKvwUH-FVZXtEQEKLRD0WMMy7p-F5hPnWofSzyUj5r9fnjSV~Uo7JWX9xRYd2rwZZPFErJeZFG-B~ePGDLdstyGyqWaNDL4e-OBjCN1UO-AKESGo0THo7L0pzRESyTuhqVut-SdS06HNxNtjEy6uT2KEJ67B8Ud~cKN7ZtvIiBYlaf4J1gqwOFpSqf0AkYHZu3iI2Ti9JGLy8g8L91LYmfp-Lfz-CXb1hLZjakf-Dm9Jz6A~iGwC8Z8lluNRKNeSSNTvRO~gD1KNb-k1dc8Ql4srKSXlOEtisKmzD7kLCWm0T8bAXg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Examples of candidates found in Gaia DR1 and DR2, with WISE pre-selection (same colour scheme as in Fig.\u00a01). W2MG1 denotes WISE objects with acceptable offsets between their 2MASS and Gaia-DR1 catalogue positions, with recomputed astrometry from our BaROQuES scripts.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/157796261/stz2200fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"157796261\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/489/2/10.1093_mnras_stz2200/2/stz2200fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611464883&Signature=tbF3Bfgr1aoVI4w7jEs-OhSn~Y5OixY5F4IT8aih8TrDrz1dwQkL9-zLg0G5aFyUE14B-VaLgwR~zP~9CpcNMFLTHnzuWhmgqpATgKUqAs9e3~nA6LXZIXQgnroKeOsxWRHfHXPJIJYhdnRP1J98oYv0hkhQx5uoF4v3KL2xDonoxDbpnTItzmlRRC3diw5fqT8yQZYP3PW-8HFqoFCBdv6AzTuGsgBcj7l1i9Cge2KZ6asFkbCDaY5tOlKZnfyQ0Vy4FhP9QvLqS2Ft3Dy--WxH8c~RYJSikbEQxi6HF1QTGEIVRRQCft957kz1mTqXV5TlZj3JkFveYAmgJ8mvyw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=157796261&ar=5548822&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Examples of candidates found in <em>Gaia</em> DR1 and DR2, with <em>WISE</em> pre-selection (same colour scheme as in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). W2MG1 denotes <em>WISE</em> objects with acceptable offsets between their 2MASS and <em>Gaia</em>-DR1 catalogue positions, with recomputed astrometry from our BaROQuES scripts.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"157796262\" scrollto-destination=\"157796262\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" alt=\"Examples of candidates found with spectroscopic (2QZ, 6dFGS), radio (SUMMS), or X-ray (ROSAT, XMMslew) surveys.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig tab</a><a data-section=\"157796262\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/489/2/10.1093_mnras_stz2200/2/stz2200fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611464883&Signature=kD3PbpGpwl~IFhIiZCInh5UfuUOh8PI0DTMe9HF6PF0Ez5NSXzqAqJnFJ7nhVABA1oPnl4ficB4sWnDP4HbLZTwwlGfenpjEACjZGl8xi48HArPgDElBQeFnykJ8u0V0qhsgr-7DTbMLWCsCdPfmCYh2clSmDu00A5LwcZV~FckLVctSJXL-GC1WDpIPAsDcbkc6fNOE2OoUTufIELpVpEm~G3NOG4KuaBCh1DuqVpIUFIIE~HQHq3LUl4Pn1mvvueC6aERSTJas25P5Dfv61uGm~HI4XNZWLz4Zpol56X6gYPsap7rLGyNFKqFFctN5oZb9~mJsGdMLrK6q2PDitA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=157796262&ar=5548822&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Examples of candidates found with spectroscopic (2QZ, 6dFGS), radio (SUMMS), or X-ray (<em>ROSAT</em>, XMMslew) surveys.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/489/2/10.1093_mnras_stz2200/2/m_stz2200fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611464883&amp;Signature=NNyCHHqj7cligPENbSFa~1gc8IY0XuCmaEkSXgwS8Lqy1zrOb-JxUObbaem19bRJMO6JBArcUowrdtiwLWx30-1flrv97kAFwlPFvtcqZphWDSUIPQ5JogPemBit8qJ19YgpWhFO2F4E7GfMuqUQWnjSsiLUN-mM41K2~q9Df6REPlpg8SdihLlI5zpDTEWzqAPp6JJppqDJ~oncyEQor-xwe9KHVh25odox~MTK7Zxqw6TqOJyFLav~fLvuXEZzQCt9ZygnEZOZd-8IcptOaTxqGF3r67suMFymIPbTf~jTF6aM41nkqiMwW4SXVBsp~kctiyLvIzJLS9Fkx2wLag__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Examples of candidates found with spectroscopic (2QZ, 6dFGS), radio (SUMMS), or X-ray (ROSAT, XMMslew) surveys.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/157796262/stz2200fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"157796262\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/489/2/10.1093_mnras_stz2200/2/stz2200fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611464883&Signature=kD3PbpGpwl~IFhIiZCInh5UfuUOh8PI0DTMe9HF6PF0Ez5NSXzqAqJnFJ7nhVABA1oPnl4ficB4sWnDP4HbLZTwwlGfenpjEACjZGl8xi48HArPgDElBQeFnykJ8u0V0qhsgr-7DTbMLWCsCdPfmCYh2clSmDu00A5LwcZV~FckLVctSJXL-GC1WDpIPAsDcbkc6fNOE2OoUTufIELpVpEm~G3NOG4KuaBCh1DuqVpIUFIIE~HQHq3LUl4Pn1mvvueC6aERSTJas25P5Dfv61uGm~HI4XNZWLz4Zpol56X6gYPsap7rLGyNFKqFFctN5oZb9~mJsGdMLrK6q2PDitA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=157796262&ar=5548822&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz2200fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Examples of candidates found with spectroscopic (2QZ, 6dFGS), radio (SUMMS), or X-ray (<em>ROSAT</em>, XMMslew) surveys.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Visual inspection is a critical step in candidate selection. Quadruplets are often clear to recognize, especially after some simple, model-based scoring (e.g. Wynne\u00a0&amp; Schechter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Doubles, on the other hand, are less obvious: contaminants include physical or line-of-sight pairs of quasars; line-of-sight pairs of quasars and stars or galaxies; pairs of compact narrow-line galaxies; and galaxies seen through two stars. Some <em>nearly identical</em> quasar pairs (or NIQs; Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>) may actually be lenses whose deflector is too faint to be detected in ground-based discovery data, especially at small separations (as discussed e.g. by Morgan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>). High-grade candidate doubles were then selected based on whether the putative quasar images had same colours, and whether a candidate deflector galaxy was visible in between, for image-separations larger than \u22481.5\u00a0times the seeing.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=157796264 id=\"157796264\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>3.3 Quadruplets</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Due to their higher number of images, with respect to doubles, quadruplets yield more constraints on the deflector potential and stellar mass fraction, and for this reason, they are especially valued probes of cosmography (e.g. Refsdal <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1964</a>; Blandford\u00a0&amp; Narayan <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>; Witt, Mao\u00a0&amp; Keeton <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Treu\u00a0&amp; Marshall <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Bonvin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) and microlensing studies (e.g. Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A quadruplet configuration requires an even closer alignment of source and deflector than doubles. The fraction of quadruplets in statistically complete quasar lens samples is estimated at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$14{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a>). The two quadruplets found within this search, WG210014.9-445206.4 and WG021416.37-210535.3, correspond to <em>Gaia</em>-DR2 triplets and are already shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. Most of the other candidates, except some radio-selected and spectroscopically selected candidates, are doubles. We emphasize that, while WG\u00a00214-2105 requires little follow-up for confirmation, in principle the chromaticity in WG\u00a02100-4452 requires a final step of spectroscopic confirmation to secure its lensing nature.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn9\" data-open=\"fn9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">9</a></sup> Still, both have been shown to be easily compatible with simple lens models (Wynne\u00a0&amp; Schechter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Two other quadruplets found in this search, at J0405\u22123308 and J0053\u22122012, have also been discovered independently within the STRIDES<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn10\" data-open=\"fn10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">10</a></sup> collaboration (Schechter\u00a0&amp; Treu, private communication). Even though they were found <em>blindly</em> by our search, using exclusively public data sets, and so would be legitimate candidates in the framework of this paper, we prefer to list them as known lenses (Anguita et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_62_1567401739549\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_62_1567401739549\" data-open=\"bib1_62_1567401739549\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; STRIDES in preparation).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=157796268 id=\"157796268\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-4>3.4 Completeness and purity</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The statistics of quadruplets is also an indication of completeness in a quasar lens search, relative to the number of objects at pre-selection. One could also use two-image lenses for the same computation, but those generally require extensive campaigns of spectroscopic confirmation, whereas quadruplets are almost unmistakeable already from photometry and simple modelling (as e.g. by Wynne\u00a0&amp; Schechter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). What follows is a simple check based on <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a> as reanalysed by Treu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) and more agnostic estimates (i.e. independent of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a>) from known lenses in the smaller footprint of KiDS (\u2248450\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup>) by Spiniello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A \u2018demanding\u2019 quasar pre-selection (e.g. <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$W1-W2\\gt 0.55+\\sqrt{(\\delta W1)^{2}+(\\delta W2)^{2}}$|\u2060</span>; Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>) produces \u224840 objects per square degree, which (adopting <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a> lensing rates) gives \u224820 lenses over the DES footprint, of which \u22482.8\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.67 should be quads. A <em>WISE</em> pre-selection like the ones in this paper produces 110\u00a0\u00b1\u00a010 objects per square degree, and should result in 7.7\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.7 quadruplets over the DES footprint.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The numbers given above, however, adopt a rough <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a> estimate that may simply be unreliable. In fact, the lensing rate of quasars is not a direct measurement of those that can actually be detected or recognized, due e.g. to the image quality of a survey or the relative importance of fluxes from quasar images and deflector galaxies. Treu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) have compared a mock sample of lensed quasars, built along the lines of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a> and rendered into the imaging specifics of the DES, and found that the estimated rates agree with the currently known lenses (including some reported in this paper) only at the bright end (<em>i</em> \u2272 18.1), and many lenses predicted by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a>+DES were probably undiscovered at fainter magnitudes. On the other hand, Spiniello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) have found that there are at least 9 quasar lenses in the KiDS-450 footprint, whereas the same <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a> estimates would have predicted 6. Therefore, the expected number of lenses (including quadruplets) should be \u22481.5\u00a0times higher, predicting \u224812 quadruplets in the DES footprint from our pre-selection criteria.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For the searches in this paper, the lensing rates should also be multiplied by the \u22480.6 success rate by which the NCSA cut-out server correctly displayed images,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn11\" data-open=\"fn11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">11</a></sup> yielding again \u22487 quadruplets over the DES from our choices of pre-selection \u2013 or 5\u201310, adopting simplistic Poissonian statistics and fluctuations in the NCSA cut-out display success rate. Then, the 9 quadruplets (discovered or recovered) in this paper suggest that the steps of target and candidate selection are reasonably complete.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to find more quads, then, the main bottleneck is that of colour pre-selection. Searches with hybrid, optical\u2013IR colours would allow one to relax the <em>WISE</em> extragalactic cuts, but in this exploration, we preferred to use the DES-DR1 only for the final stage of visual inspection in order not to impose a prejudice on the optical colours of lensed quasars upon our searches.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The number of quadruplets also indicated the expected purity of the whole candidate sample. With the figures above, we would expect \u224860 candidate doubles to actually be lenses. The current sample of \u2248100 candidates then suggests a purity of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\approx}60{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>. The success rate of ongoing spectroscopic campaigns (Spiniello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) confirms this estimate.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=157796275 id=\"157796275\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have discovered two previously unknown quadruplets, WG210014.9-445206.4 and WG021416.37-210535.3. We have independently discovered another two (J0053\u22122012, J0405\u22123308) found independently within STRIDES (Anguita et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_62_1567401739549\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_62_1567401739549\" data-open=\"bib1_62_1567401739549\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; STRIDES in preparation), which we prefer to list among other known lenses in the DES footprint.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The use of five different selection methods, over spectral ranges ranging from X-ray to radio through optical, has resulted in 100 quasar lens candidates over the DES-DR1 public footprint. The number of quadruplets found in this paper suggests that the searches are reasonably complete and that the main bottleneck is the very first step of object pre-selection</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">All of the searches involved a step of <em>WISE</em> pre-selection, imposing some loose cuts on colours in order to isolate extragalactic objects, and results in two main clusters of candidates based on whether their photometry is quasar dominated or galaxy dominated. Due to the capabilities of the DESaccess server with large cut-out queries, at least at the time when these searches were performed, approximately two-thirds of targets in the DES-DR1 footprint were properly displayed, so another \u224850 candidates may be still awaiting discovery.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The depth of lens searches is still an open issue. Despite the nominal depth (<em>i</em> \u2248 22.5) of the DES public data, current campaigns over the DES footprint are covering the brighter end (<em>i</em> \u2272 18.5, as shown by Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Spiniello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). This is partly due to the completeness limit of <em>Gaia</em>, and the need to identify promising candidates upon visual inspection. From the searches in this paper, a pre-selection-based e.g. radio or X-ray emission seems to aid the identification of lens candidates at fainter (optical and IR) magnitudes than has been possible so far (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=157796280 id=\"157796280\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 Deeper and sharper <em>WISE</em> pre-selection</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">At the stage of <em>WISE</em> pre-selection, we are currently limited by two factors: the uncertainties in <em>W</em>1, <em>W</em>2, <em>W</em>3 magnitudes; and image resolution. First, the searches are cut at <em>W</em>1\u00a0&lt;\u00a017 and <em>W</em>2\u00a0&lt;\u00a015.6, since the magnitudes of fainter objects are more affected by Earth-shine and become quickly unreliable. Secondly, the \u22486\u00a0arcsec (full width at half-maximum, FWHM) image resolution of <em>WISE</em> prevents any comparison of the mid-IR colours of different components, which at these wavelengths should be unaffected by reddening and microlensing and would then make a powerful selection criterion.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Forced photometry upon <em>WISE</em> cut-outs, using object positions from sharper surveys (like Gaia or the DES), would alleviate these issues and enable a deeper and sharper search, maximizing the information content of <em>WISE</em>. This, of course, requires that multiple components are identified by the optical surveys and that their separation is wide enough (\u22732.5\u00a0arcsec) so that the magnitudes inferred through forced photometry are reliable. From a re-reduction (Meisner, Lang\u00a0&amp; Schlegel <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) and forward modelling of <em>WISE</em>/Neo<em>WISE</em> survey tiles, forced-photometry magnitudes are currently available for the SDSS (Lang, Hogg\u00a0&amp; Schlegel <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) and the DECaLS (Dey et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) footprints, covering \u2018Northern\u2019 declinations above \u221220\u00a0deg. By using <em>Gaia</em> multiplets as a base for forced photometry, a search based on mid-IR (deblended) colours may be extended to the whole sky. However, the completeness of the resulting sample would be ill characterized, as the current releases of <em>Gaia</em> fail to properly deblend lenses (e.g. WGD\u00a00150, WGD\u00a00245, Agnello <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) that are clearly deblended into multiplets by other surveys such as the DES.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Another way of increasing depth and imaging resolution, in the BaROQuES approach, would be to replace 2MASS with deeper surveys, such as UKIDSS (Warren et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) or VHS (McMahon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). However, their sky coverage is not homogeneous, whereas 2MASS covers the whole sky, and their application to a DES search is of limited use since their overlap with the DES footprint is only partial. Wile UKIDDS is primarily a Northern hemisphere survey, VHS was planned to cover the whole Southern hemisphere, but<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn12\" data-open=\"fn12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">12</a></sup> it is mostly limited to \u221220 \u2264 Dec. &lt; 0 and \u221250 \u2264 Dec. &lt; \u221240, and not homogeneously.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=157796284 id=\"157796284\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>4.2 Towards the LSST</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">While near-IR surveys (e.g. VHS, UKIDSS, and VHS) are ideally suited for chromatic offsets, due to the different colours of sources and deflectors, optical surveys can be a valid alternative. Lemon et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2_121_1567403907218\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2_121_1567403907218\" data-open=\"bib2_121_1567403907218\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) have successfully used SDSS instead of 2MASS, and our BaROQuES procedures have been applied with success to the KiDS-DR3 450\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> footprint (Spiniello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). In the near future, LSST (SV due 2022, SciOps due 2023) will enable the extension of these searches to the whole Southern hemisphere.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Despite the deluge of multi-epoch data from the full survey, the foreseen volume of nightly observations is still manageable, and automated procedures for chromatic offsets can be run on a nightly basis. This pipeline-oriented approach will then bring the discovery of lensed quasars to the same, high-cadence pace of transient discoveries. Ideally, chromatic offsets can be computed among different bands within LSST, without the recourse to external surveys like <em>Gaia</em> or 2MASS, provided nightly data are deep enough to guarantee robust astrometry in separate bands.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=157796287 id=\"157796287\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3>4.3 <em>Gaia</em> DR3, DR4, and <em>Euclid</em></h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The DR2 of <em>Gaia</em> provided additional information over DR1, such as blue and red pass-band magnitudes (<em>G</em><sub>bp</sub>, <em>G</em><sub>rp</sub>), as well as parallax and proper motion, for sources towards the bright end. It has a safety cut-off at \u22480.5\u00a0arcsec nearest neighbours, which prevents the discovery of small-separation lenses through multiplet recognition but may be reassessed in future releases. The pipeline proper motions of known lenses are not necessarily small (Spiniello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), and colours from <em>G</em><sub>bp</sub>, <em>G</em><sub>rp</sub> can only be used for the brighter candidates.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The final <em>Gaia</em>-DR4 release, due in 2020, is planned to provide low-resolution spectra of all detected <em>Gaia</em> sources. This would provide a selection of lens candidates based uniquely on <em>Gaia</em>, bypassing broad-band colour selection, through the detection of emission lines from the source quasars. This approach closely resembles the Hamburg-ESO strategy of isolating quasars based on their low-resolution spectra and following them up with higher imaging resolution, but it would be applied over the whole sky and down to fainter magnitudes.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Beyond the spectroscopic and multiplet selection in <em>Gaia</em>, an obvious step forward will be the Euclid space mission (Laureijs et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). The lessons learnt from the <em>Gaia</em> pipelines, in deblending objects into multiple sources and extracting spectra, will be essential to the development of lens searches within Euclid. In these all-sky perspectives, significant improvement is needed on the final stage of candidate selection, whether it is based on direct cutout modeling or direct visual inspection. Dedicated deblenders are being developed to this purpose (e.g. Chan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), but they still require manual \u2018tuning\u2019 to the specifics of each survey, and a considerable amount of visual inspection.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=157796291 id=\"157796291\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-4>4.4 Beyond <em>ROSAT</em>: <em>eROSITA</em></h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The optical and X-ray choices of pre-selection are quite complementary. On the one side, X-ray-selected sources populate the faint end of the <em>WISE</em> and <em>Gaia</em> magnitude distribution, and sometimes miss <em>Gaia</em><span class=\"monospace\">source</span> counterparts. On the other, only two of the known lenses in the DES are detected by our <em>ROSAT</em>\u2013<em>WISE</em> search, and in general X-ray-selected lenses are a minority among the CASTLES sample.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the near future, <em>eROSITA</em> (Merloni et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) promises a \u224820 deeper coverage than <em>ROSAT</em> in the soft X-ray, and the first ever all-sky survey in the hard X-ray. The forecast of \u2248100 detected objects per square degree, over the 4-yr span of the survey mission, is comparable to the <em>WISE</em> extragalactic selections used in this paper, and based on completely independent spectral signatures. In particular, from the expected number of active galactic nuclei (AGNs) with redshift 1 &lt; <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> &lt; 3 and the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a> estimates, <em>eROSITA</em> should detect \u2248120 lensed quasars over its 30\u00a0000\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> footprint, a quarter of which would have an obscured AGN as a source.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=157796294 id=\"157796294\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" data-legacy-id=ack1>ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We thank the anonymous referee for a remark on Completeness and Purity that spawned the discussion in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4</a>, and T.\u00a0Treu and P.\u00a0L.\u00a0Schechter for discussions of issues with translating <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a> forecasts from detectability to discoverability. CS wishes to thank N.\u00a0R.\u00a0Napolitano for interesting discussions about lens searches. AA wishes to thank P.\u00a0L.\u00a0Schechter for support and encouragement, and gratefully acknowledges hospitality by the Harvard ITC in 2018 February\u2013April, where the <em>Gaia</em>-DR2 searches were run.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">CS has received funding from the European Union\u2019s Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme under the Marie Sklodowska-Curie actions grant agreement no. 664931. AA is supported by a grant from VILLUM FONDEN (project number 16599). This project is funded by the Danish council for independent research under the project \u2018Fundamentals of Dark Matter Structures\u2019, DFF -6108-00470.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This research made use of the cross-match service provided by CDS, Strasbourg. This research has made use of the NASA/IPAC Infrared Science Archive, which is operated by the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, under contract with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. This publication makes also use of data products from the 2MASS, which is a joint project of the University of Massachusetts and the Infrared Processing and Analysis Center/California Institute of Technology, funded by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the National Science Foundation.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This project used public archival data from the DES. Funding for the DES Projects has been provided by the U.S. Department of Energy, the U.S. National Science Foundation, the Ministry of Science and Education of Spain, the Science and Technology Facilities Council of the United Kingdom, the Higher Education Funding Council for England, the National Center for Supercomputing Applications at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, the Cientifico e Tecnologico and the Ministerio da Ciencia, Tecnologia e Inovacao, the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft, and the Collaborating Institutions in the DES.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" Tololo Inter-American Observatory, National Optical Astronomy Observatory, which is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy (AURA) under a cooperative agreement with the National Science Foundation.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=157796299 id=\"157796299\" class=\"backfootnotegroup-title\" >Footnotes</h2>\r\n<div content-id=\"fn1\"><span Institutions.</p></div></span></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=157796313 id=\"157796313\" class=\"backreferences-title\" data-legacy-id=ref1>REFERENCES</h2>\r\n<div class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\"><span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Abbott</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">T. class=\"close-reveal-modal\" href=\"javascript:;\"><i class=\"icon-general-close\"></i><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Close</span></a>\r\n</div>\r\n \n    </div>\n\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n<script src=\"//cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/mathjax/2.7.1/MathJax.js?config=TeX-AMS-MML_HTMLorMML\"></script>\r\n\r\n\r\n<script src=\"//cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/promise-polyfill@8/dist/polyfill.min.js\"></script>\r\n\r\n    <script type=\"text/javascript\" src=\"//oup.silverchair-cdn.com/UI/versioned-asset/637439192420341521/UI/app/jsdist/footer.min.js\"></script>\r\n    <script async=\"async\" src=\"//s7.addthis.com/js/300/addthis_widget.js#pubid=xa-5265518246c10183&domready=1\"></script>\r\n\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n    \r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n    <!-- Copyright 2001-2010, IBM Corporation All rights reserved. -->\r\n    <script src=\"//ouptag.scholarlyiq.com/ntpagetag.js\"></script>\r\n    <noscript>\r\n        <img src=\"//ouptag.scholarlyiq.com/ntpagetag.gif?js=0\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" border=\"0\" hspace=\"0\" vspace=\"0\" alt=\"Scholarly IQ\" />\r\n    </noscript>\r\n\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"ad-banner js-ad-riser ad-banner-riser\">\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-AdBlock widget-instance-RiserAd\">\n         \n    </div>\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n\r\n</body>\r\n</html>\r\n\r\n", "Status": "Complete", "Action": "Scanned all subtables", "Table captions or footers": {"Overview": ">For full access to this pdf, sign in to an existing account, or purchase an annual subscription."}, "Pandas format": {"Table 2": {"Status": "Complete", "Action": "Processed via pandas", "Inspection": {"Notes": {"Skip cause table not important": "", "Message on table quality": "Known lenses. No new info."}}}, "Table 3": {"Status": "Complete", "Action": "Processed via pandas", "Inspection": {"Notes": {"Table correctly loaded": "", "Detection table": "", "Message on table quality": "Not all reported candidates are new.", "Lens Kind": "2"}, "Table map to MasterLens database": {"System Name": "Object name"}}}, "Table 4": {"Status": "Complete", "Action": "Processed via pandas", "Inspection": {"Notes": {"Table correctly loaded": "", "Detection table": "", "Message on table quality": "Not all are new candidates.", "Lens Kind": "2"}, "Table map to MasterLens database": {"System Name": "Object name"}}}}}}, "Tables status": "Complete", "Paper Overview": {"type_of_reference": "JOUR", "Title": "Quasar lenses in the south: searches over the DES public footprint", "authors": ["Agnello, Adriano", "Spiniello, Chiara"], "author_address": ["AA(European Southern Observatory, Karl-Schwarzschild-Strasse 2, D-85748 Garching, Germany; DARK, Niels-Bohr Institute, Lyngbyvej 2, DK-2100 Copenhagen, Denmark), AB(European Southern Observatory, Karl-Schwarzschild-Strasse 2, D-85748 Garching, Germany; INAF - Osservatorio Astronomico di Capodimonte, Salita Moiariello, 16, I-80131 Napoli, Italy)"], "journal_name": "Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society", "volume": "489", "publication_year": "2019/10/1", "start_page": "2525", "end_page": "2535", "keywords": ["catalogues", "galaxies: formation", "dark matter", "Astrophysics - Astrophysics of Galaxies", "Astrophysics - Cosmology and Nongalactic Astrophysics"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2019MNRAS.489.2525A", "abstract": "We have scanned 5000 deg<SUP>2</SUP> of Southern Sky to search for strongly lensed quasars with five methods, all source oriented, but based on different assumptions and selection criteria. We present a list of high-grade candidates from each method (totalling 98 unique, new candidates), to facilitate follow-up spectroscopic campaigns, including two previously unknown quadruplets, WG 210014.9-445206.4 and WG 021416.37-210535.3. We analyse morphological searches based on Gaia multiplet detection and astrometric offsets, fibre-spectroscopic pre-selection, and X-ray and radio pre-selection. The performance and complementarity of the methods are evaluated on a common sample of known lenses in the Dark Energy Survey public Data Release 1 (DR1) footprint. We recovered in total 13 known lenses, of which 8 are quadruplets. Morphological and colour selection of objects, from the WISE andGaia-DR2 surveys, recovers most of those known lenses, but searches in the radio and X-ray cover regimes that are beyond the completeness of Gaia. Given the footprint, pre-selection, and depth limits, the current number of quads indicates that the union of these searches is complete, and the expected purity on high-grade candidates is {\u2248}60{{ per cent}}. Ongoing, spectroscopic campaigns confirm this estimate.", "doi": "10.1093/mnras/stz2200", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:1805.11103", "issn": "0035-8711", "number": "2"}, "Inspection status": "Incomplete"}
